Attention Mr. Phelan,

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find fiscal statement for the September quarter.

As instructed, I have listed all accounts outstanding. The total, less balance on hand, $1618.78. The balance of per capita grant due is $4158.08 which will leave me with $2537.30 as at the beginning of the quarter. At the same date last year there remained of the per capita grant $462.02. This year, therefore, shows an improvement of $2075.28.

During the year I have received from New England Company grant $2250.00 so that it would appear that I have used for the conduct of the school the per capita grant plus $174.72 from the New England Company grant. On the other hand I have paid a number of accounts for major repairs which normally have been chargeable to these funds, viz., roofing the gardener's cottage (material only) $107.00; roofing material for the whole new wing, i.e., pupils' diningroom and the section between it and the main school, $172.55; a new coil for hot water heater $125.00; new cream separator $150.00; plumbing and alterations necessary to make the boiler function properly, $173.54. Total, $728.39. Major Randle was consulted re these repairs.

It is plain, therefore, that, in spite of rising costs, the current expenses have been kept well within the per capita grant. I trust that this record will give to you satisfaction and assurance that the utmost care and economy consistent with efficiency has been exercised.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
As you have been recently advised, monthly statements should be submitted in future in the manner already requested.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant enclosing the financial statements of the Mohawk Institute for the months ended January 31 and February 28. It is evident from the February statement that the Principal has no funds on hand for the month of March. I suppose we cannot criticize him too severely in view of the fact that he has been absent from the school a great deal owing to illness during the current quarter. However, the Department trusts that he has now fully recovered his health and I should appreciate it if you would bring to his attention our desire to have the finances in such shape that the quarterly grant will carry him over the next quarter. This is the financial position which we trust he will reach very shortly.

Yours truly,

discussed and the Department can rest assured that this office will
do all possible to see that the Principal achieves the financial

everything have risen in the past two years, and of course the
quarter just ending and the previous quarter are the most expensive
in the year, being the winter months.

absence and while this office was in charge, no expenses were auth-
orized or incurred other than those of routine nature, such as food,
etc., so that this office was not in any way responsible for the
lack of funds on hand, and except for paying salaries and two or
three special accounts, most of the settlement of outstanding accounts
was left until Mr. Snell's return.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle, Supt. Six Nations, Brantford, Ont.

I have your letter of the 18th instant, enclosing the November financial statement of the Mohawk Institute. Under the heading "Liabilities" there is the following entry: "New England Company -- boiler -- $2500." It is difficult to understand this entry. In the first place there is no necessity of mentioning the New England Company. In the second place I cannot understand why the expenses incurred in connection with the boiler have not been paid. We forwarded the Principal a cheque for $2500 for this purpose and he included this amount in his October financial statement as a receipt during that period. I should appreciate your comments and explanation.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

This will acknowledge your 32-0-3 of the 15th of December in connection with the November financial statement of the Mohawk Institute.

In reply you are advised that the boiler account has not been paid because it had been returned for correction and only now has been received back.

The plumber so far has not submitted his account because he has not yet fully completed his work.

This office was checking on this situation before your letter arrived, and can assure you the matter will be cleared up as rapidly as possible.

Lt.-Col. E.P. Randle,

Indian Superintendent.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The herd sire has been purchased and we have bought him for $472.50. He was delivered the other day and as yet the invoice has not come. I am securing an extended pedigree so that we can see the strength of his blood line. This pedigree will cover four generations. The milk production is also listed.

Will it be possible to have the $150. so that I can have matters cleared up for the December statement. In instances such as this are the invoices sent to your office? Mr. Haworth is very pleased with the animal. We sold the cow for $96.00 and that will be used to help to meet the price of the new sire. I have $155. from the former sire.

Yours very sincerely,

Rev. J. Zimmerman, M.A., B.D.

20 July 1946.

Lt.Col. E. P. Randle,  
Superintendent, Indian Office,  
Brantford, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Having completed three months as acting Medical Officer to the Mohawk Institute, I beg leave to draw your attention to some of the medical and hygienic conditions that have come to my notice.

I am happy to inform you that my relations with the Principal and Matron have been most cordial, and that I have received the utmost cooperation from all members of the Staff.

In my opinion the general health of the pupils has been very good, with a notable absence of respiratory infections.

Forty cases were referred to Lady Willingdon Hospital during this period. They consisted of 36 cases for removal of Tonsils and Adenoids; 2 cases of Acute Rheumatic Fever; and 2 cases of Interstitial Keratitis found to be Wassermann positive and requiring anti-syphilitic treatment.

Two cases of Vincent's Stomatitis were referred to Dr. Bradley Linscott for dental treatment.

Several cases of Impetiga Contagiosa were found and cleared up rapidly with sulphathiazole ointment.

General inspections of all buildings were made and many unsatisfactory conditions were found.

Dishes were being washed in soapy water too infrequently changed, and dried with none too clean dish towels. It was recommended that they be scraped clean, washed in soapy water, rinsed in clear water, dipped in HTH 15 solution and dry racked.

--Roller
Roller hand towels were found to be in use in the pupils' wash rooms. On several occasions they were found to be very dirty and unsanitary. In my opinion they should be discarded and paper towels provided.

It was found that the female pupils are using cloth sanitary napkins which are washed in the school laundry. It is strongly recommended that they be dispensed with, and disposable sanitary pads be supplied instead.

There are no seats or tables in the boys' recreation room. It is suggested that barrack room benches and tables might be obtained for this purpose.

Flour and sugar were found stored in bags and exposed to mice. It was recommended that such commodities be purchased in one bag quantities and kept in covered metal containers.

Bread was found kept in open baskets, exposed to flies and mice. It was recommended that screened open shelves be built for storing bread.

In my opinion the refrigeration space is presently very inadequate, and the equipment is not in good working order.

There is no ice available to cool milk at the dairy, and insufficient refrigeration space for its storage.

The outbuildings are infested with rats, and the Brant County Health Unit has been consulted regarding means to eradicate this menace.

It is hoped that arrangements can be made to carry out the above mentioned recommendations without undue delay.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

Yours very truly,

(signed) H. Palmer
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

This office is enclosing for your information a report received from Dr. H. Palmer, Medical Officer to the Mohawk Institute.

Of the recommendations made, the Principal has already carried out those with regard to washing dishes, storage of flour and sugar, and bread.

Seats and tables are to be made for the boys while carrying out repairs there during the holidays.

May the other matters please receive your consideration, as they mostly entail considerable expenditure beyond the present income.

Lt.-Col., E.P., Randle,

Dear Colonel:

I do not know if you received my wire or not. I am very sorry to have misjudged the number of quarterly returns on hand. I felt that I had plenty and when I went to type the completed forms to hand on to Colonel Randle there were only two. I have them written in long hand for record here but wish to copy them. If you have not already done so could you send at once the blue quarterly returns.

You were asking about Dorothy Jamieson. I was sorry to hear that she has gone home and is doing nothing. I told Col. Randle hoping that he might be able to do something. She is a capable girl.

Dr. Palmer is most anxious that I engage a young practical nurse. The girl he has interviewed has been receiving $27.00 per week. Nurses are very scarce here in Brantford.

Could you arrange to forward an advance so that I can pay our bills?

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
F. J. Zimmerman, M.A., B.D.
Principal.
January 19, 1948.

Colonel B.F. Neary,
Supt. Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

My dear Colonel:

To-date I have not received the quarterly return forms. I am sorry that I erred in misjudging that I had sufficient. My reports have been ready for ten days. We have the quarterly returns completed in long hand. I prefer to have copies.

In case you have not received my last letter could I have an advance so as to pay the bills for this month.

I am very sorry for my error. You will be glad to know that we have a fine outdoor rink and the pupils are enjoying the rink immensely. I hope to have a hockey team.

Yours in haste,

[Signature]

Mr. Scott:

Mr. Scott,

Plans and specifications were prepared and tenders invited for the alterations and additions required to the Mohawk Institute, Brantford. Advertisements inviting tenders appeared in the Brantford papers and The Contract Record of Toronto.

The proposed work consists in the providing of a new vapor system of heating for the existing building, and the proposed addition; the remodelling of the existing unsanitary plumbing installation with the installing of new plumbing fixtures in the boys' and girls' toilets. Additional accommodation is provided in an addition to the building for a dining room, kitchen and boiler room with necessary store-rooms, also a new laundry. The following tenders have been received for the work:

The Schultz Brothers Co. Ltd., Brantford.......$35,180.00
A. J. Cromar................................."...........35,981.00

Both of the above mentioned tenderers have submitted with their tender the required deposit security. As the tender of the Schultz Bros. Co. Ltd. is the lowest and a fair and reasonable price for the work, I beg to recommend that it be accepted.

MEMORANDUM

MR. SCOTT,

On Tuesday and Wednesday of last week, I made an inspection of the alterations and additions now being carried out by the Schultz Bros. Co., Ltd., of Brantford, to the Mohawk Institute.

The work is progressing very satisfactorily and so far, the workmanship and materials are the very best. The footings are all in for the foundations and the basement walls are under construction. The necessary partitions have been removed in the basement to provide for the new toilet rooms, one for the boys and one for the girls, and the plumber is running his pipes for this work.

There were a few items in the plans and specifications which Mrs. Boyce, the Principal, would like changed, such as the style of urinal; the closets; 38" radiators in place of 36"; the door of boiler room and the glass in the windows of the dining room. I am listing below the estimated cost of the changes asked for by Mrs. Boyce, and I would recommend that the contractors be authorized to make the changes as enumerated below. I may say that I went into the cost of these items carefully with the contractors, and the figures quoted below are fair and reasonable for the work.

Changing of urinals from wall to stall pattern...$112.00
Changing of water closet from low tank seat operated to slow and valve operated.................. 39.00
Changing of a portion of radiation from 38" to 28" in order that the radiators may be placed under the windows................................................. 83.00
The enlarging of the boiler room door to 7' in place of 4' as shown.............................................. 34.00
The substituting of cast glass in place of the ordinary glass as specified in the dining room. This glass is semi-transparent and will prevent the children playing around the building from looking into the dining room................................. 48.00
With reference to the sewage disposal for the building, it will be necessary to connect same with a 9" sewer which is approximately 200 feet from the building, to take care of the drainage of the addition and the new toilet rooms. The present sewer pipe leaving the building is not large enough and has not enough fall to give satisfactory drainage. It drains to an old pipe line to the North of the building. It is proposed to carry a new sewer pipe from the building to a 9" iron which was installed recently for the use of the Glue Factory and which passes through the school property.

I discussed the sewage disposal with the Plumbing Inspector for the city of Brantford, and he informed me that the 9" sewer which it is proposed to use was ample in size for all requirements of the glue factory and the school, and that the city of Brantford would approve of the connections being made to this sewer line.

As the city of Brantford will not allow rain water collected from the roofs to be emptied into the sewers, it will therefore be necessary to run a separate rain water pipe to carry away rain water from the building, and it is proposed to carry this pipe in the same trench with the sewer pipe and empty it into a pit filled with broken stones approximately 200' from the building. The estimated cost of the work is $596.00, and I beg to recommend that the Contractors for the school be authorized to proceed with the work at once, in order to have it completed before the ground freezes, the cost of same to be added as an extra to their contract.

I may add that the point where the new sewer pipe will join the 9" main, is approximately 25' below the level of the basement of the building, also the outlet for the rain water pipe will be at the same distance below the level of the basement floor. The connection is on the East side of the building, and the ground slopes away on this side, which will provide excellent drainage facilities.

Dear Sir,

You will no doubt recall our discussions when I was in London, with reference to the Mohawk Institute, at Brantford, and the needs of the institution, particularly in regard to the additions to buildings. I am sure that the Governors of the New England Company will be glad to learn that we are now carrying out the very extensive improvements which I outlined at that time.

The main building is lacking in sanitary conveniences and, in order to remedy this condition, we are making alterations in the basement to provide toilet rooms for the boys and girls. In these toilet rooms will be installed plumbing fixtures of the latest design.

There is no adequate refectory accommodation in the institution, and, to provide this much needed improvement, we are constructing an addition at the rear of the building. This addition will contain in the basement, a large dining room and a new kitchen and store rooms adjacent, directly connected to the main building. Over the dining room will be constructed at a later date, an assembly hall with accommodation for approximately 300 people.

The heating system as installed at the present time, consists of one small hot water boiler and two warm air furnaces. These do not provide sufficient heat to make the building comfortable during the winter months. To remedy this condition, we are installing a vapor system of heating in the entire building. This also includes the building of a new boiler room adjacent to the building, at the rear.
The present alterations also provide space for a laundry and the necessary machinery will be provided in order that the greatest efficiency in this branch may be attained.

The contract for the work was awarded some time ago to the Schulte Bros. Co. Limited of Brantford, Ont., at a cost of $35,000.00. The work is well under way and it is hoped that the contract will be completed before the end of this year.

When the alterations have been completed, I shall be pleased to send you photographs in order to give you some idea of the improvements which have been carried out, after the completion of which I think the Mohawk Institute will be well equipped in all departments to carry on their very efficient and successful work with the Indian children of that locality.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Ernest Matthews, Esq.,

MR. SCOTT,

In connection with the alterations and additions now being made to the Mohawk Institute, laundry machinery will be required to complete the laundry. You will note that this range is made with only one fire box to heat one, two and three ovens, and that this is placed at the end of the range.

By the Lang special construction, no heat can possibly get up the smoke pipe until it has completely encircled the flues of the range and around the ovens. This is because the smoke flue is at the left hand side of the fire box, as you will note by the illustration.

By the Lang special method, every oven is evenly heated, as well as the cooking top, and the cost for fuel is practically reduced to half, as compared with ranges having two fire boxes to heat two ovens.

The large polished French cooking top of the Lang Range is fitted so tight that not a particle of heat is wasted through this top, nor can grease or dirt accumulate. MEMORANDUM.

MR. SCOTT,

I beg to report that on March 7th, I made an inspection of the alterations and additions now being carried out to the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, by the Contractors, The Schultz Brothers Company Limited of that city.

The work under their contract is nearing completion, the main work yet to be done being a portion of the painting and the installing of metal ceilings in the toilets in the old building. This work will, in all probability, be completed in the next two weeks.

All of the work carried out by the above firm has been exceedingly satisfactory and, when completed, will provide a much needed accommodation at this institution.

In accordance with your instructions, I made a careful examination of the interior of the institution, and beg to report the repairs which are necessary to remedy the unsatisfactory and in many cases, unsanitary existing conditions:

GROUND FLOOR: The existing floor on the ground floor is of soft wood. It is badly worn and new hard wood flooring is required.

The main corridor is poorly lighted and to remedy this condition, it will be necessary to install glass in the doors of the several rooms opening out of the corridor.

New stairs are required in the boys' end of the building, leading to the basement. The existing dining room in the basement will be converted into a boys' recreation room and this stair will be required to provide access from the recreation room to the class-room and dormitories above.
All of the corridors, officers' rooms and offices require to be decorated and all of the wood work painted.

As there is only one bath room provided in the building for use of the staff, an addition should be arranged for on the ground floor. There is a small bed room which can be converted economically into a bath room.

The girls' class room which is too large for the purpose, should be divided by a partition in order to provide a class-room and a sewing room. The walls of this room will require decorating and wood work painted.

The existing sewing room which will, in future, be used as a staff dining room, requires decorating and a small room partitioned off one end for use as kitchenette.

All of the stairs throughout the building require metal treads as the existing wooden ones are badly worn.

**FIRST FLOOR:** The existing night toilets opening out of the boys' and girls' dormitories are very poorly located, and on this account, are in an exceedingly unsanitary condition. It will be necessary to provide new toilets which should be located on an outside wall, in order to provide them with a window for ventilation. This can be economically and satisfactorily arranged by partitioning off a small corner in each of the dormitories.

The corridors on this floor require hard wood flooring as the existing soft wood floor is badly worn and exceedingly difficult to keep in a sanitary condition.

Two staff bed-rooms require decorating and painting.

Existing staff bath-room requires hard wood flooring walls and woodwork painted.

**BASEMENT:** Metal ceilings are required in the boys' and girls' recreation rooms. They are at present plastered and in an unsatisfactory condition.

The main corridor requires painting and the installing of a new partition to separate the boys' and girls' recreation rooms.

All of the outside windows and doors in the existing building will require to be refitted, and the space around the
frames packed with oakum. In their present condition it makes it very difficult to keep the building at a uniform temperature, more particularly on the side from which the wind is blowing.

I am of the opinion that all of the above work can be carried out at an approximate cost of $4,500.00, and I beg to recommend that these repairs be undertaken by day labour as, owing to the nature of the work, it will be possible to utilize to advantage the services of the larger boys attending the institution, employing where necessary, skilled labour. This procedure would be the most economical and satisfactory way of having the work done. All materials required will be purchased after obtaining competitive prices in the regular way.

The Principal has asked that if any repairs are carried out, to the interior of the building, that they be done at as early date as possible. As you know, they have been considerably upset since late last Fall on account of the alterations being made, and they would appreciate having all of the work contemplated at this institution finished up as soon as possible.

If you approve of having the work as above mentioned carried out by day labour, I shall make arrangements for the necessary labour and material on my next inspection of the work at the Mohawk Institution.

I may say that if the repairs as above outlined are carried out, the Mohawk Institute will be well equipped and the building in a very satisfactory condition to carry on their educational work.

Memorandum,

Honourable Charles Stewart,

I beg to send you herewith a report of the Architect with reference to the necessity for certain repairs required at the Mohawk Institute, Brantford. I would recommend that this expenditure be allowed; Parliament had provided funds for the alterations and improvements which were carried out under contract with Schults Brothers, and I have to report that we will be, fortunately, able to make the additional expenditure, outlined in the Architect's memorandum, without charging it to Public Funds.

The New England Company sent me, the other day, a thousand pounds to apply to improvements on the school, and I propose to use this money for the purpose now under discussion. This one thousand pounds is a portion of the total amount received by the New England Company for their interest in a property owned by the Six Nations, in which there was a joint interest on the part of the Indians and the New England Company. They had spent a certain amount of this fund on the Lytton Industrial School, a school which is their property but which is now under lease by the Department. They wish now to pay back that sum gradually, in the interests of the Mohawk Institute at Brantford.

Dear Mr. Orr,

There are several places that I should have visited earlier but I have been so busy that I have not had time to get in touch with you.

I am still working on the re-decoration here, but I have not yet finished all the other work. We were very busy at the beginning of the year and I decided not to engage fresh men just then. Now that we have been able to break them in and then leave them for a few days to observe, I have been able to hire the men who feel most comfortable doing the work assisted by the boys and the farm-hands whenever possible.

At the present time we have to complete the bath-room and two bedrooms on the Principal's flat, besides refinishing a few odd pieces of floor. We have not touched the dining-room, but there need attention in the new Dining Hall that has been used for storage with the burlap finish until we shall have to refinish it as soon as we see further signs of sweating.

We have used up the supply of paint set aside for this work, so if you could let me know how much there is left, in order that I may be able to use it to the best advantage.

Our heating plant has worked like a charm and we have found it all possible to get the proper amount of heat when we have our windows closed, but we have tried.

For next month so you will see that the improved winter conditions are quite worth while. You have no idea how comfortable we have felt this winter without having to worry over severe "gales".

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

H. Rogers.

Sir,

I have some difficulty in getting the walls of the Dining Hall of this school dry. At first I thought the dampness was due to "sweating" of the new materials but I have recently discovered that the main water supply pipe to the out-buildings runs under the floor of this new wing.

It is apparent from my last water bill that there is a leakage somewhere around and I have been unable to locate the same. The only conclusion that I can come to is that the leakage must be under the floor of the dining hall and is also responsible for the dampness that exists. Should this be the case, fear results would be serious in the event of severe frost this coming winter.

I am enclosing a rough sketch that will explain the situation and see if we can find any way of getting out of the difficulty than by laying a new pipe to the barns. I was only able to find the location of the pipes from an old employee and understand that the lines at present in use were laid some thirty years ago.

Could you please give me your instructions in this matter.

I wish to point out that all bills have been paid promptly and the reputation of the institution is not suffering in the business world because of any outstanding accounts.

Mr. Rogers welcomed any scheme that would assist him in the general financing in the future and I promised that favourable consideration would be given to the necessary replacements and repairs to plant. Further, special expenditures only should be met from the New England Company grant and the principal welcomed the assistance of the Department in the administration of this money. I advised him to write to the Charter Clerk, informing him that the Department would fund the money in a special trust account and would assist in the administration in the future. The Department also would correspond with the New England Company in this connection.

The principal expressed his willingness to carry advances on the per capita grant from time to time over periods and to make a determined effort to get our financial basis. He will receive, as heretofore, $160 per capita grant and will use this entirely for current expenditure. Special requirements will go to the Department for decision.

There are small accounts for interior decorating which will be paid from appropriation during the next year and cannot be charged to the present school year.

Department of Indian Education.
October 21, 1924.

Memo:

On the 24th and 25th ultimo Mr. Phelan audited the books of the Mohawk Indian Residential School and made a study of the expenditure for a period of fifteen months ended June 30th last. He prepared a comprehensive report, which is hereunder, and I was able to discuss with Mr. Porter upon the occasion of my visit to the school last summer, the best methods of placing the institution on a sounder financial basis.

I am convinced that the deficit of approximately $5,000 in current financing is accounted for largely by the increase in additions to stock and agricultural machines. The interior decorating of the main building was necessary if the farm was to be put on a paying basis and the decoration was advisable for several reasons and particularly because of the large number of visitors to the institution. I know of no Indian residential school in Canada, that is subjected to the same continuous stream of visitors as the Mohawk.

The tuition period in the case of the Mohawk Institute is short. The reasons for this are the delinquency following holidays, when pupils return we could not be brought back without considerable difficulty and perhaps unpleasantness, they are off the roll. This all results in too large a number of garden activity, which in turn affects the finances of the institution. The principal provides the superintendent Morgan cases of delinquency considered undesirable to have the pupils returned under unsettled conditions at present on the roll. No drastic action will be taken. If the situation quietly resolves, they will be asked to come back.

The principal has a good idea of the financial condition of the school, or expenditure during the past fifteen months. Further, he is familiar with feed and the natural increase of the source of revenue. Besides, I may state that the principal is acquainted with the supplies. The expenditure in the past been provided by the management.

Sir,

I have been giving the question of mechanical transport some consideration lately and by making a comparison of costs and utility I have come to the conclusion that we should revert to horses so far as this Institute is concerned.

Undoubtedly, we have reaped a great benefit from the trucks but they are now in such a condition of wear that they can only be a continual source of expense.

The Ford ton truck which was handed over to us by the Department of Soldiers Civil Re-establishment is about seven years old and worn out; whilst the Kelly is expensive to operate and under the new taxes would be required to work continually to be a utility.

We have used our truck for all town work and the marketing of our garden produce. It is obvious that this has been economical in so far as it has left our teams at home at work and has also saved time but under the existing conditions I would feel disposed to purchase a democrat or market waggon and use an old horse which is now no longer to hold his place in a team on the land.

However, the necessity of some means of quick transport seems to me to be more or less urgent and I would recommend that the two trucks be disposed off and a half-ton Ford runabout be purchased.

The cost of maintenance of a small truck of this description is very small and would be fully recouped by the time it would save and also the feed and care of another horse which we would be compelled to buy should we completely dispose of motors.

To condense the foregoing, might I trade the Ford ton truck and the Kelly truck upon a new Ford runabout and be given permission to purchase a market waggon which I think I could buy for about $50.00.

Sir,

During Mr. Perrier's recent inspection of this School I took up the matter of building a more suitable Pig Pen than that which we now have to use. At present we are unable to maintain a steady supply of pigs since it is not possible on account of dampness to raise good pigs during the winter months. Our present building is of cement construction and I could use it very well for my stock which will need more room next winter on account of the increased number I am now able to keep.

I have succeeded in raising the standard of our hogs to a point where they are in good demand and we are getting about 80% Select Bacon Hogs. This adds materially to the income from our farm and when I mention that our hog pen has produced $425 during this month it will be seen that the Hog industry is a very profitable one for us to follow. There is also a demand for our stock for breeding purposes and I feel that better accommodation would help me considerably in financing.

I was fortunate enough to meet Mr. Orr a few days ago and asked his criticism on my plans and feel quite confident that we can erect a Pen at a minimum cost that will prove satisfactory.
However, the School finances at present would be taxed rather severely should I draw on them for the total cost of this building and I would like to suggest that the Department provide the necessary lumber and I think our present profits would be able to cover the cost of erection.

I would propose hiring a carpenter who is experienced in barn construction that I can engage for 65 cents an hour and would supply him with help from the boys and outside staff. This would keep the cost of construction down to a minimum. I have some windows and roofing that could be used.

I think the cost of necessary lumber would be about $250.

Sir,

Replying to your letter dated 9th April with regard to purchase of an electric stove, I beg to state that the finances of this school do not permit of this action in a general way but the circumstances governing this action forced our hand.

Four years ago wiring was carried out with a view to installing this stove as soon as we could afford to do so. Last fall we felt the need of this piece of equipment and asked the Department to make this purchase as we were still unable to make the outlay. On receipt of your reply dated 16th October I received the impression from the wording of your letter that the Department was not prepared to create a precedent by making such a purchase for an Industrial School. We still refrained from making the outlay until in January we were in sorry straits. Owing to the fuel shortage we were only able to obtain coke for cooking purposes. This was $4 per ton and as it burned so quickly it was very extravagant. More than this it was impossible to heat the ovens and consequently all the cooking had to done on top the stoves. Our housekeeper had an awful time and was becoming daily more discouraged as she found it impossible to serve the meals at the proper times. The only solution of the problem was to cut down the amount of cooking in the main kitchen.

It was impossible for me to procure anything but coke and coke was rapidly burning out the kitchen range. I was faced with a very high fuel bill, a damaged range, inefficiency and possibly the loss of the best housekeeper we have had in years, and the installation of the electric range appeared to be the only way out of my difficulties.

Our electrical dealer gave us a very good figure on the range and agreed to take $25 per quarter in payment should I find myself unable to make earlier settlements. The total cost of the outlay was $125.

With the foregoing facts in mind I thought I was taking a very wise step in making this purchase.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott

While in Brantford last week I visited the Mohawk Institute to see what progress is being made with the new roof on the main building, and I may say that the work is progressing satisfactorily but slowly on account of the weather conditions.

While at the Institute the Principal brought to my attention the urgent need of a suitable dryer for the laundry. They have a very fine laundry room at the Mohawk Institute which is equipped with a washer and an extractor, both of which are in excellent condition, but they have no means of drying the clothes except by hanging them around different parts of the building, which is very unsightly and unsatisfactory. The type of dryer furnished to other schools is one known as a Junior Drying Tumbler and costs $900.00. In addition to this there will be required a 5 H. P. high pressure steam boiler which will cost $255.00. If funds can be found I would strongly recommend that the above equipment be furnished to the Mohawk Institute.

Size and Style
The inside cylinder shall measure 30 inches in diameter by 12 inches in length, constructed of galvanized woven wire, and shall be of type.

Frames
Shall be of heavy cast iron, bolted together and connected by heavy stiffening angles, and shall support housing cylinder, fans, coils and driving mechanism.

Housing
Shall be of No. 16-gauge galvanized sheet iron. Shall be riveted to iron frames and made tight to prevent the escape of heat and air. The door shall be constructed of No. 16 galvanized sheet iron, hung on heavy wrought-iron strap hinges and securely latched by malleable-iron clamps making it close fitting and preventing the leakage of air and heat.

Shall be equipped with clean-out door at bottom between fans.

Two upright castings shall be bolted to top of frames for tub door to rest against when open.

Cylinder
Shall be constructed of No. 21-gauge, .110-inch diameter, galvanized woven wires, rolled after being woven, so that the intersections shall be interlocked. Shall be riveted to inwardly projecting cast-iron trunnions and re-enforced by wide hoops. Shall be further strengthened by four channels riveted to trunnions. Shall be constructed with 3 galvanized, cast-iron ribs projecting 4 inches into cylinder, securely riveted to the woven wire and bolted to the trunnions. Door shall be of No. 16 galvanized sheet iron, perforated, hung on heavy hinges, and fitted with heavy door latches.

Coils
Shall be located within the housing at rear and consists of 202 lineal feet of one-inch iron pipe connected at each end with right and left return bends.

Fans
Shall be equipped with 2 single fans of the multi-blade type 7½ inches in diameter, mounted on fan shaft beneath cylinder, for circulating air through the coils, and thence through the cylinder and out through an 8-inch duct leading to rear of machine. Shall be fitted with screened air intake. Fan shaft shall be equipped with renewable bearings.

I beg to report that on June 17th I made a careful examination of the cow barn at the Mohawk Institute and found the building to be in such a dilapidated condition that it is unsafe. The building was originally poorly built, all of the main supports in the walls are broken, the floor joists are rotten and the flooring both in the loft and the barn badly out of repair. They require a cow barn to accommodate their herd of forty milking cows. To provide this accommodation it will take a barn 56' x 100', with ample loft space for the storage of feed, and this will cost $4,800.00 if the building is built by day labour under the supervision of the Principal. I would, therefore, recommend for your consideration that a new cow barn be built by day labour, under the supervision of the Principal, all of the materials to be purchased after first obtaining competitive prices. As they will require storage space for their feed this summer the building should be commenced as soon as possible.

Sir,

Herewith account for Gas stove supplied this Institute.

In reply to your enquiries this stove is of the Garland manufacture, a Canadian product; this stove replaced a coal stove which became useless in about five years wear. During that time we were continually making repairs and replacements and cost of upkeep became excessive and in selecting a new stove I was keen to install such that would give us the highest efficiency with the minimum of cost for fuel and upkeep.

Since installing this range we have been able to prepare all the meals in this Institute at a cost of 58cts per diem and have no trouble whatever.

Whilst the original cost is somewhat higher than the old coal stoves I feel that its installation will prove a very economical move eventually.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Referring to your letter dated July 18th, I would like to point out that we have offered to co-operate with Mr. Snell in every way possible but I do not see that Mrs. Rogers should be burdened with the extra work of preparing rooms for workmen and cleaning after them for some other person to enjoy.

Mrs. Rogers has always kept a perfectly clean and tidy house and I consider it absolutely unnecessary to engage men to polish already carpeted floors. This work will have to be carried out during the school holidays when a number of the staff and pupils will be absent and it would be unreasonable to demand extra work from those remaining.

There will be staff rooms vacant that the Snell family can occupy while the work they wish carried out can be done.

I am only too anxious to assist in every way possible to give Mr. Snell a good start but I cannot allow Mrs. Rogers to attempt this extra work.

Oct. 26-29

Dear Sir,

I understand that Mr. Orr intended to pay another visit to this school but as he has not come I am bringing to your attention an urgent need we have of a shed for our implements, which are standing out for lack of one. I have been told by the farmer that it was Mr. Orr's intention to recommend the building of an implement shed on the wall of the cattle barn that was torn down. This would give us abundant room as it would also make available for this purpose the basement of the old barn as well.

With this in view I have obtained an estimate of the cost of this work from Mr. Smith who has done considerable work here in the past. He estimates that to repair the floor and build a ten-foot building on the old wall which is 100' x 36' would cost £2450.00. The materials from the old barn would be used as far as possible.

Trusting that this request may receive your immediate and favorable consideration, I am,

Your obedient servant,

November 8, 1929.

Memorandum:

Rev. Mr. Snell, who visited the Department today, has explained the need of an adequate implement shed at the Mohawk Institute. The old barn and foundation and the first storey - the roof of which is at the main grade level - can be used for this purpose, but there should be a 9 ft. structure with pitch roof erected on top. The old barn material can be used for siding and for part of the roof, but it will be necessary to purchase some further materials and to engage a carpenter foreman with one or two carpenters. The school carpenter and older boys will give some help. The structure is 100 ft. x 36 ft., and the cost may reach as high as $1,200. All implements can be properly stored when the new building is erected, and, in addition, young stock can be housed.

This improvement appears to be necessary, and, as funds can be found in the current Appropriation, I wish to recommend it to your favourable consideration.

[Signature]

April 10, 1930.

Memorandum: Dr. Scott.

I beg to report that on Monday, March 31st, I made an inspection of the Mohawk Institute at Brantford. Seven years ago alterations and improvements were made to the interior of the Institute and a portion of a new wing built on the rear. Since that time, however, only minor improvements and repairs have been made to the exterior and interior of the building. When the rear wing was erected the Chapel, which was provided for in the plans, was omitted, and a temporary roof provided over the basement rooms, the intention being to complete the wing at a later date. The Reverend Principal is very anxious that the Chapel be erected this summer. The estimated cost is $10,000.

The water from the City of Brantford is very hard and at the present time it is being chlorinated with the result that the Institute are having difficulty in operating their laundry. The heater which supplies hot water to the building was found on examination to be completely clogged and arrangements have been made to install a new one. In order to provide soft water for the laundry I would recommend that the existing soft water tanks, which have not been in use for many years, be cleaned out and that the down pipes from the save troughing on the building be connected to these tanks; that a small automatic electric pump be installed and connected up to the hot water system. In addition to the installation of the pumping plant repairs will be required to the save troughing. The cost will be approximately $500.00.

An examination was made of the fire escapes. They consist at the present time of steel platforms with doors leading from the dormitories and the descent is made by means of steel ladder secured to the wall. These fire escapes have been up many years and are not of the modern type. In case of fire the children would have considerable difficulty in reaching the ground. I would recommend that new steel stair type fire escapes be installed in place of the existing ones. The cost would be approximately $2,500.00.
Hand operated fire gongs should also be installed in each of the rooms of the dormitories also new fire hose for the interior of the building.

When the alterations were made to the building seven years ago a new toilet was provided for in the basement in the girls' end of the building, and the old toilet was patched up. This old toilet at the present time is in a dilapidated condition and very unsanitary. In order to put it in proper shape it will be necessary to install four new closets. The cost will be approximately $300.00.

No interior decorating has been done in the building since the alterations were made and seven of the staff rooms are badly in need of redecorating. The cost will be approximately $150.00.

None of the windows in the school are provided with fly screens. The cost of providing screens would be approximately $500.00.

A considerable amount of fencing is required on the property, and I asked the Reverend Principal to take measurements of the amount required and submit an estimate of the cost to the Department.

Some dormitory space is required for the boys and to provide this additional accommodation it is suggested that the space on the top floor of the building at the boys' end be finished off as a dormitory, same as was done a few years ago on the girls' end of the building. The cost will be approximately $2,500.00.

The following is a summary of the alterations required with the estimated cost of each.

Dear Sir:

At the request of Mr. Snell, Principal of the Mohawk Institute here, I have examined the Steam Heating System in the above Institute and find that the chief trouble with the System is that the Condensation cannot return freely to the boiler through the present return trap that is in use.

This condition causes the water of condensation from the System to back up in the returns which prevents the Steam from reaching the radiators properly, the result being that the Heating efficiency of the System is very much reduced.

I would advise that the present boiler return trap be removed and a Condensation pump be installed to pump the water of Condensation back into the boiler.

The present returns should be connected together and carried into the receiver of the feed pump through a 2" float trap.

This would ensure a positive and automatic return of the water to the boiler and a proper supply of steam to the radiators. I believe this will satisfactorily remedy the trouble there has been in this system.

The cost of the necessary automatic Feed Pump and Receiver and Float Trap etc., would be $450.00. This price does not include the cost of pipe, fittings, and labor necessary for installation of the above as this cost would be difficult to estimate and we could only charge this on the basis of time and material required.

Trusting that I may receive your authority tops ahead with the work which will be carried in our usual prompt and efficient manner, I remain,

Yours truly,

Department of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

(1) Will you please send me official letter authorizing the repairs and improvements which are being made at the Institute this summer? I understand that it simplifies matters in the office when such a letter is quoted.

(2) We are having trouble getting sufficient hot water and the cost seems to me to be excessive, averaging $35.00 per month. I believe we should have much better satisfaction and at less expense if we had a gas ring installed in the hot water heater. The cost would be small and would add to the efficiency of the laundry. I hope you may consent to the installation of gas in the heater.

(3) Another heating problem has been the difficulty of heating the principal rooms and the large amount of water which has to be drained from the dry return pipes each day owing to the fact that there is not sufficient pressure to force the water back. This results in inefficient heating and a considerable increase in the amount of coal consumed in heating the cold water that is introduced. Mr. Oliver has, I believe, submitted a report and
a recommendation based on the opinion of the heating engineer of Dunham's Ltd. I should be very glad if this or some other solution of our difficulty could be effected before the time for starting the boiler.

I regret to be making so many requests for improvements at this time but these seem to be particularly urgent.

Trusting that they may receive your favourable consideration, I am,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
SEPT. 4, 1930.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 25th I beg to say that you may arrange for the repairs and improvements to the Mohawk Institute as instructed by the Architect of the Department a short time ago. The total cost of the work must not exceed the amount already mentioned, namely $5,800.00.

You may also arrange for the installation of a gas ring in the domestic hot water heater.

With reference to paragraph 3 of your letter regarding the heating system, I beg to say that as it will cost approximately $1,000.00 to install a pump on the return line to the boiler, it will be impossible to undertake this work this year, as there are no further funds available. Before undertaking any further work requiring the services of a plumber and steamfitter kindly await further instructions from the Department, when the name of the firm to be employed for such work will be sent you.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I am writing to ask for authority to construct a cistern to supplement our present supply of soft water for the hot water system. The only expense would be the cement necessary as we can do all the work ourselves and have a supply of gravel suitable for the work. I regret to have to ask for this but I find that our pressure system recently installed is of very little use without more soft water. I should have verified the size of the cisterns we have before asking for the pressure system I know. But the farmer had cleaned them out just before I came and he assured me that they were 12 feet square and 12 and sixteen feet deep. As they were filled with water I did not have them emptied to verify his statement. We find now, however, that they are less than half the dimensions he said, so now after asking for and obtaining a pressure system because we had so much water, I have to ask for another cistern because we have a pressure system. The small additional expenditure will, however, be more than justified by the saving
that would accrue. I know that the allotment for improvements here has been exhausted and I have thought that if the work is authorized I might meet the expenditure from the per capita grant and still save money.

Trusting that you will overlook my indiscretion and also authorize the cistern, I am,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Sir,

I have had the steam heating engineer of Crane & Co. here and he has given me a quotation for the condensation tank and pump for returning water to our boiler including all pipes and fittings amounting to a total of $318.97. The equipment can be installed by our own mechanic so that this would be practically be the entire cost. There would be a small additional expense for connecting the electric motor.

With our present equipment the wet returns are not forced into the boiler and we have to draw off over 700 gallons of water per day. This, of course, has to be replenished by filling the boiler with cold water. So that we are losing both water and fuel for lack of the equipment recommended.

This is the same equipment which was estimated to you some time ago at about $1000.00. By doing the work ourselves and buying from the wholesaler we can reduce
the cost as quoted above. I am enclosing the quotation as submitted by their engineer.

I am aware that the funds for this year are already overassigned but I was thinking that this amount might be supplied from the New England Co. grant. It would mean a considerable saving in coal as well as preserve the pipes from lime deposit which must be excessive with that amount of fresh hard water going in daily.

Trusting that you may be able to find a way to finance this improvement, I am,

Your obedient servant,

Last summer we installed lightning rods on His Majesty's Chapel to the Mohawks near Brantford Ontario and at that time our man took a look at some of the other buildings about the institute to see whether the rods on them were in good shape. He found that two barns there which should be protected with lightning rods were not rodded and he intended at that time calling the matter to your attention but we were very busy at the time and on until the snow came and this was never done.

Nearly every insurance Company doing business in Ontario grants reductions in the rate on farm buildings when equipped with lightning rods because their experience is that there is less loss on rodded than on unrodded buildings. This is borne out by the record of twenty-six insurance Companies given on page sixteen of booklet "Universal Protection" sent you on this mail.

I quite appreciate that the Dominion Government does not carry insurance but I submit that if it is good business for insurance Companies to grant reductions in rate on rodded buildings based on their experience then it should be good business for the owner of a building to have it rodded because the danger of loss is reduced.

In Ontario a record was kept by forty insurance Companies for twelve years and this showed that two thirds of all rural barn claims settled during the period were due to lightning so that when a man rodded his barn he cut off two chances out of three of its being burned.
The Universal Lightning Rod Company
High Grade Lightning Rods
Fixtures and Supplies

HESPELER.

It would not cost very much to rod these buildings now when copper metal is so low and if you would be interested in having an estimate we would be very glad to run over to Brantford which is only a short distance from here and get the information for you and then if you decided to have the work gone on with we could attend to it the first thing in the Spring.

We would be very glad to hear from you on the subject in due course.

Yours Truly,

The Universal Lightning Rod Company.

MAIN BUILDING:

I visited all the rooms in this building and found everything looking very clean.

Since my last visit on August 1st, 1929, the following improvements have been made:

(a) Two new dormitories have been provided on the third floor and substantial fire escapes erected from both the girls' and the boys' dormitories. The doors opening on the fire escapes have been changed to open out and have been equipped with panic bolts.

(b) Pressure system has been installed to make it possible to use soft water in all hot water taps.

(c) New toilets and slop basin as well as new cement floor in junior girls' toilet room.

(d) New lockers in boys' playroom and in sewing room, also new tables and benches in diningroom to accommodate extra boys.

(e) Extensive repairs to the existing plumbing which have resulted in school being much warmer.

(f) The whole of the exterior painted by the boys and the whole of the interior, with the exception of the dormitories also painted or varnished by the girls.

(g) Almost all the Principal's flat has been redecorated.

The Principal intends to write the Department about April 1st and make a formal request for the following additional improvements:

(1) Hardwood floors in two of the bedrooms on the Principal's flat.

(2) Awnings for the verandah opening out of the Principal's livingroom.

(3) Redecorating of the officers' rooms.

If funds are available at the time the Principal writes, I would recommend that his requests be given favourable consideration.

Dear Dr. Scott,

I trust you will pardon my appealing directly to you but I am so anxious that the Chapel for the Institute should be built this year that I wish to bring the matter to your personal attention.

First (to begin in the manner of a preacher), this is the hundredth year of service for this Institute. The building of a chapel would appropriately mark the centenary. Surely, too, a school which has so long a record of service should not be kept without a chapel.

Second. The school attendance is now so large that there is not sufficient accommodation in the senior schoolroom which is the only place available in the building. The pupils are sitting three in every seat and some have four. It is manifestly impossible to maintain the proper spirit for worship under such conditions.

I am finding that the emphasis given to the religious training is having a very decided effect for good in the general conduct of the pupils and is, I am sure you will agree, the most important part of their training. The lack of a chapel for the daily services is a serious handicap.

Knowing, therefore, that there will almost certainly be a pruning of the estimates I am taking this opportunity to plead that our chapel may be given to us this year.

I would be pleased to receive early assurance that we are to have it this summer as I have in mind to appeal to some friends of the Institute to provide some of the furnishings in memory of former principals.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I am attaching hereto our formal proposal in duplicate covering the installation of one (1) Jones #25 Automatic Coal Burner together with fan equipment and automatic control for the Leonard Firebox boiler in your main building.

The stoker we are offering is capable of a continuous feed of 250# per hour which will develop the capacity rating of your boiler.

From your operation, as you gave it to me, you are at present burning an average of 200 tons of Bituminous lump coal - cost per ton $6.70. Based on numerous tests which we have conducted over the past 30 years, we find the average boiler plant efficiency operating under your conditions to be 55%. Taking this as a basis and taking into consideration increased efficiency under the stoker operation together with the differential in the price per ton on stoker coal, namely $5.12 per ton for Youghegany Henderson, we estimate that you would effect a total operating saving of $818.00 per annum. You will notice that you will save approximately $1.58 per ton on coal itself. This saving, representing as it does close to 50% interest on the cost of the stoker installation, makes the proposition a very satisfactory one.

This stoker which we are offering is not only very rugged but of simple design and as near fool-proof as it is possible to make a stoker. It has been operating under similar conditions in a great many buildings for the past 30 years with great success.

Regarding the Spann's Daisy #6 boiler in the Greenhouse, we are submitting a separate proposal covering the installation of our Pyramid Shaking Grate system together with fan system and automatic control.

With this system we recommend your using #1 American Buckwheat coal which, as we found last week, can be obtained from the Shepherd Coal Company at $7.45 per ton. You are at present burning,

Dear Sir,

Owing to the warm winter we have been unable to put in any ice for use this summer. In addition the old refrigerator is practically out of commission though we should have tried to get along this summer without asking for a new one if we had been able to get a supply of ice.

I have obtained a very reasonable price on an electric refrigerator large enough for all our requirements from A.F. Dehl of this city. The refrigerator is a General Electric in a box manufactured to their specifications by the Ruddy Company of this city.

The price for the plant installed is $1260.00, less 10% discount leaving a net price of $1134.00. This includes sales tax and can be reduced by that amount if it is not subject to the sales tax, in which case the cost would be $1088.54.

I trust that there may be sufficient funds in the New England Company grant to enable you to authorize the purchase of this equipment.

I should appreciate it if the authorization were made as soon as possible as the warm weather we are having makes it difficult to keep milk and meat without refrigeration.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter No.32-0-5, 5th inst., re accounts forwarded for payment by the Department for payment. I understand the objection to the payment of the account from John Bishop & Son as there were some items for the farm included in the account. The account of Scarfe & Co., however, was authorized in the same way as all accounts for paint and hardware used in permanent repairs ever since I took over the Institute. In addition to the written authorization, Mr. Farrier told me in conversation re such matters that the Department were willing to pay for paint so long as the school would put it on. We have, therefore, tried to keep the building in first class condition in this respect. This is the more important on account of the many visitors we have during the summer. The paint used this last quarter was used to paint the interior and exterior of the laundry, kitchen, scullery and pupils' dining-room as well as much varnish as was needed in various places throughout the building. So you will see that a great deal of value was received from the expenditure of a small amount of money. You will have noted from the dates that this work was done from time to time as the Boys' Master had opportunity, which makes it difficult to estimate costs.

When I was chairman of the property on the school board we had a rule that any expenditure of $100 or over should be submitted to the board. Expenditures under that amount were at the judgement of the property committee. Inasmuch as there are continually needed small repairs to the plumbing, carpentry, painting etc., which we can do ourselves but for which we need materials, all of which I am able to purchase wholesale and some of which we need to keep on hand, would it be possible to give me authorization to make purchases of this kind up to a certain amount as the need arises? Purchases exceeding the amount
specified would require, of course, special authorization. I am quite sure that such an arrangement would result in a considerable saving in the cost of upkeep. When we have have the trades figure on the work or have to buy from them we have to pay a profit amounting to about 100% on all materials used and I have been able to establish connections with wholesalers and manufacturers which have resulted in very considerable savings on materials.

Trusting that some such arrangement may commend itself to you and that you will reconsider the payment of Scarfe & Co.'s bill for paint, I am,

Your obedient servant,

Principal.

P.S. You may depend upon my best efforts now as always to conserve to utmost the funds and to cooperate in every way in measures of economy.
Ottawa, May 13, 1932.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, in reference to the account of Scarfe & Company, covering the cost of paint supplied for use at the Mohawk Institute, and with reference to expenditures incurred on your authority from time to time for materials used in the upkeep of repairs at the school.

In reply I have to say the Department requests that, when materials are required in excess of $25, you report the matter to the Department, giving particulars and the cost involved, and receive authority before incurring the expenditure. Small quantities of paint, enamel, nails, washers and other inexpensive hardware and small pieces of lumber should be purchased from school earnings. If, during any period, five or six necessary purchases on account of buildings or mechanical plant amount to $25 or $30, you may send the account to the Department for consideration. It must be remembered that our funds are extremely limited, and it is necessary that a close check be kept on our expenditure.

Regarding the account of Scarfe & Company, I would request that you arrange for payment of same, this time, from school receipts.

The Department notes that you will give your best efforts in all measures of economy in connection with the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir,

When I was in Ottawa last, Mr. Ferrier suggested that I might be needing to replace the car here. I thought that it would be unnecessary at that time, but I find that it will need new pistons immediately and our mechanic tells me that other repairs are likely to be needed in the near future. I have, therefore, made inquiries and find that, by taking a 1932 model left over from last year I can get an extraordinary trade-in allowance on the Hudson, which was purchased in 1929.

The two best offers I have received have been:
(1) Buick Sedan, list price $1775, for the Hudson and $1050.00, an allowance of $725.
(2) Chrysler 8 Sedan, list price $2475.00, for the Hudson and $1250.00, an allowance of $1225.

I sincerely hope that the New England Co. funds are sufficient at present for you to feel warranted in approving the purchase of a car. I feel that the Chrysler is by far the best buy and as it is $200 more in cash outlay than the Buick I would be willing to take care of that difference personally, if necessary, if you will authorize its purchase.

Trusting that I may receive a favourable reply at an early date, I am,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa, February 28, 1933.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, requesting authority to purchase a new car to replace the Hudson car which you now have.

Owing to the adverse exchange situation, the amount received from the New England Company is considerably lower than formerly. In addition, the per capita allowance is being decreased by another 5%. Under these circumstances, the Department considers that the present is not an opportune time to incur any expenditures that may be avoided, and we are not prepared to authorize the purchase of a new car.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

To Mr. Barker,

The Department requires a small stoker for the greenhouse at the Mohawk Institute. This school is in the Federal District of Brant, but is situated just on the outskirts of Brantford City.

One year ago, a stoker was supplied for the main building by the Lilley Engineering Company, whose representative is Mr. Barker of Brantford. This stoker has proven very satisfactory and Mr. Barker now offers to supply a similar make of stoker, but a smaller size, for the greenhouse at a cost of $25.00. Funds for this purpose are available from the grants received from the Lion England Company and funded in Savings Account 467.

It is estimated that the installation of this stoker will result in a saving of approximately $25.00 a year in the cost of fuel and I consider that it is advisable to secure the stoker.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Buskard,

The Department requires a small stoker for the greenhouse at the Mohawk Institute. This school is in the Federal District of Brant, but is situated just on the outskirts of Brantford City.

Some years ago, a stoker was supplied for the main building by the Riley Engineering Company, whose representative is Mr. Barker of Brantford. This stoker has proven very satisfactory and Mr. Barker now offers to supply a similar make of stoker, but a smaller size, for the greenhouse at a cost of $525.00. Funds for this purpose are available from the grants received from the New England Company and funded in Savings Account 457.

It is estimated that the installation of this stoker will result in a saving of approximately $325.00 a year in the cost of fuel and I consider that it is advisable to secure the stoker.

Please let me know if it will be in order to give the business to the Riley Engineering Company.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

I note your criticism re sending of the telegram. I certainly should not have sent one had it not been urgent. The coils in our heater burst that morning and we have had no hot water since and shall be without until I receive your instructions. This creates serious difficulties in the laundry etc., so I hope something may be done speedily. I am sure you will agree that a telegram under the circumstances was justified.

The present heater was installed by a man in Paris and it has been difficult to get any service from him. It has not been satisfactory as it does not furnish sufficient hot water for our purposes and though I complained to the Manufacturers nothing seemed to be done. Had it been installed by the local Gas Company it would have been serviced free of charge and we should have been saved considerable expense. I, therefore, strongly advise that, if a new one is installed, it be purchased from The Brantford Gas Co., whose tender I am enclosing.

I did discuss the matter of a new heater with Mr. Phelan last Autumn and again, briefly, at the O.R.A. in Easter week when he advised that, if the present heater could be made to serve, we should wait until next fall before asking for a new one. We were endeavoring to do this but when the coils burst, I thought the most economical plan would be to install a new one now, thus saving the one hundred dollars repairs to the old one.

Dear Sir,

We have recently had a report made by Mr. Smith, the Engineer, regarding the condition of the buildings at this Institute. The report indicates that there are several areas of concern. It was noted that the buildings are subject to fire hazards due to the age of the structures and the materials used.

The new Underwriters' Laboratory obtained a full report on the buildings concerned and the Underwriters Assurance Company made seven suggestions for improvements all of which are considered important from the point of view of safety. They are as follows:

1. The roof has a solid brick covering, excepting the area over the main building, which is covered with tiles. The tiles are in good condition but the roof itself shows signs of wear and tear.

2. Secure a certificate of approval for all electrical wiring in the buildings. This certificate should be obtained from the local Electrical Inspector.

3. Provide one chemical extinguisher, of the standard 2½ gallon type, for each 2,500 square feet of floor space in main building, including main addition.

This would require two in new addition and three on each floor of basement, first and second floors, with one in each dormitory in attic, or a total of thirteen for the building.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs (RC) Volume (C501, file 406-5, part 1)
The Deputy Superintendent General

24th April, 1936.

There is now a good supply in the building, and if brought up to the above standard full credit may be secured.

4. Caretaker's mops, polishes, etc., should be stored in a cupboard in the fire-proof boiler room.

5. The main building, new addition and original building, is at present one fire area and of course both sections take same rate. The new addition contains the heating, kitchen and laundry, all of which affects the rate.

There is one opening from new building to old building basement and we strongly recommend that a standard automatic closing fire-door be installed on this opening. The cost would be approximately $1.50 a square foot.

6. We also recommend a standard automatic closing fire-door on opening to boiler room which is of fire-proof construction with the exception of the present wood door on opening.

Note - These doors may be secured from Turnhull & Cutcliffe Company, Brantford, Ontario.

7. Electric irons in sewing room to be equipped with pilot light and keyless socket.

These are all most material to the rate of premium which the Company will have to pay and indeed it is pointed out that No. 1 should be attended to without delay. I trust I am right in assuming that the Department will have these seven points attended to forthwith.

In addition the following suggestions were made but these would appear to be the concern of the Department only, since I am informed that they do not affect the premiums to be paid. The suggestions are:

1. Protect your interests as owners by insuring farm truck [This is not of personal concern by him]

2. Insure under a fine arts cover, Queen Ann silver and bible. This cover would include fire, theft, damage in transportation, etc., at a cost of approximately 2% for three years, subject to fair valuation.

In the appraisal of contents there is no value given for the above old silver, Bible, and records, and as these articles are no doubt extremely valuable, some difficulty might arise in case of loss in arriving at a fair value in order to apply the co-insurance clause on contents. By insuring these articles under a fine arts cover they would be more adequately protected and at the same time the value of these articles would be eliminated from the general contents and thus avoid the possibility of
The Deputy Superintendent General

24th April, 1938.

argument as to value in case of loss.

3. Place insurance on boilers; this insurance including cost of inspections now made by Government Inspector.

4. Provide standard hose houses for three hydrants (one over hydrant near horse stable not in good repair); and install at least 200 feet of standard rubber-lined hose in each house with hydrant wrenches, axe, crowbar, lantern, etc.

In addition to private equipment, we recommend the organization and training of a private fire brigade among the staff and senior male pupils.

5. In greenhouse, the metal smoke flue pipe has a clearance of only 3 inches from basement joists. This clearance should be increased by cutting away 3 x 10 timber nailed on bottom of joists and protecting woodwork with asbestos and metal.

Attention was also drawn to the following point: there is at present no Public Liability Insurance and in the event of fire at the Institute resulting in loss of life among the pupils, fairly heavy claims might be expected from their parents. This would of course be a matter for the Department but I point it out as having been mentioned to us.

I should be much obliged if you would let me know as to the action proposed to be taken on the above-mentioned suggestions 1 to 7 so that I may inform the Western Assurance Company.

Dear Sir,

Major Randle and I have gone thoroughly into the cost and construction of a suitable henhouse and equipment. Assuming that we should keep 400 or 500 hens the cost would be in the neighbourhood of $2000 provided we are given a free hand in the engagement of the workmen.

We visited the leading poultrymen of the neighbourhood and also spent an afternoon with Professor Graham, head of the poultry department at the O.A.C. Everyone was very willing to give us all the information possible. They all advised that it would be unwise to purchase laying hens this Fall for the reason that there would be great risk of losing many of them. The price would be prohibitive, and the production of eggs would be seriously affected. Our best policy, therefore, would be to buy day-old chicks this Spring.

In that case we should need three or four colony houses costing about $65 each this Spring and the laying pen could be built during the Summer.

The main difficulty lies in the management of the hens. A good man who understands the work could make a profit. On the other hand there might be a rather serious loss. The consensus of opinion was that suitable men are very hard to find. In order to give full time employment to a man we should have to keep at least 1000 laying hens which would double the cost of pens and equipment. Mr. Lager is doing well with the hens we have, considering the equipment, and I think that if he had a short course at Guelph this Winter he might make a success with them.

I shall await your instructions, of course, before proceeding further in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Principal.
In my opinion it would be wiser to have first a first-class flock of laying hens, and then, after a thorough experience is gained in the maintenance, character, feeding and production, it might then be advisable to branch out into raising hens from the baby chick stage.

I agree that four hundred or five hundred hens is about the reasonable number for the Institute to have, whether they are obtained by buying that number of young pullets next season at a suitable time or whether by buying 1000 baby chicks in the Spring and discarding roosters and culls which would probably provide us then with about our estimated requirements.

Mr. Snell's figure of $2000.00 to build and equip a thoroughly modern hen house is about correct. A house to accommodate five hundred hens built entirely by outside labour, complete with nests, laying boxes and feeding troughs, would cost approximately $1300.00. Most of this sum would be the cost of material, the labour amounting to only about $250.00 of that sum.

It is my opinion by using experienced labour used to erecting such buildings, it will in the long run, cost less than by trying to utilize school labour wholly or in part.

Mr. Lager is certainly interested in poultry and I believe like the Principal, that if he were permitted to take the short course at Guelph this winter, he would receive a thorough grounding in the practical side of raising poultry and producing eggs which would give him confidence necessary to make a success of a flock at the Mohawk Institute, whereby, not only would suitable and necessary food be produced for the children, but a training helpful to them in making a living in the future might be achieved.

Your obedient servant,

G. P. Randall
