Sir:

With reference to your letter 32-0-1 of October 7th last, in connection with a new hen house at the Mohawk Institute, I am enclosing a letter from the Principal and my own comments are submitted.

As the Reverend Principal states, we have made a very thorough examination of the general problem of a suitable building, and the care, maintenance, and cost, of a flock of hens necessary for the requirements of the Institute.

All the experienced men we consulted were emphatic in recommending against attempting to purchase laying hens this Autumn, as they claim that only young pullets should be bought and as the laying season has actually commenced, it would be very poor policy and generally detrimental to our interests to move laying birds to new surroundings.

We were also informed that it was not only almost impossible to secure a really good laying strain of bird, once the pullet laying season commenced, but even if we could, the price per bird would be prohibitive and make the initial outlay for the flock too costly.

Judging from this information the only time to buy a flock of the size we should require would be in the early summer when the young pullets have grown beyond the dangerous early stages, but just before they begin to lay.

Most chicken men seem to favour the idea for a school like the Mohawk Institute that it would be wise to buy baby chicks and raise them to maturity ourselves. Mr. Snell favours this plan as he feels it would be excellent training for the boys to have a working knowledge of poultry from the start. In some ways that appears sound but this is the only thing in which I differ a little from the Principal as I am somewhat dubious of doing this at the present stage.

Sir;

In reply to your letter 32-0-5 of the 2nd, instant with reference to the raising of poultry at the Mohawk Institute I be to submit and recommend that the following plan be carried out.

After a thorough discussion of the matter with Mr. Snell, and consulting further prominent poultry men in the locality, I am prepared to recommend that the Principal of the Mohawk Institute be permitted to purchase 100 baby chicks.

This number can be purchased at 13 cents each, or a total of $13.00. Allowing for the usual mortality, weeding out and roosters, there should be left about the 800 young pullets required.

The young roosters can be sold in a few weeks as broilers, for which there is a ready market, and will amply repay their original cost and feed used to bring them to marketing condition.

The advantage of this I am advised by expert opinion is that generally speaking, it is better and more satisfactory in every way to buy chicks a day old and then place them in surroundings where they remain until mature and ready to lay, than to buy such hicks at ten weeks old, at a greatly increased initial cost, and where often mortality is high as a change in surroundings frequently has adverse results.

Consequently in the face of this advice I am prepared to alter my previously expressed opinion, particularly in view of the fact that Mr. Lefr, who will be responsible for the care and raising of the chicks, is keenly interested in doing this, and it is perhaps wiser not to dampen the eager enthusiasm of one whom I feel sure will make a success of the venture.

The chicks can be purchased at the price quoted from the well known local firm of Schultz Bros, and will be Leghorns in which I agree entirely with Mr. Snell, as the most suitable breed.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter No. 5 of the 15th instant in connection with the cost of repairs for the heating system of the Mohawk Institute.

In reply would advise you that I have gone into the entire circumstances of the matter with the Principal, the Rev. H. W. Snell, and also made as far as possible, an examination of the work carried out.

I have also examined the accounts of the plumber carrying out the work, Mr. Oliver, and verified with him the nature and necessity of the work.

It appears that after the work Mr. Snell had received authorization for had commenced, in uncovering and taking out sections of the heating system to be repaired, it was found that adjoining sections were badly laid, rusted or corroded right through, making replacement a necessity.

As an instance of this it was found the entire piping in the large dining hall was rusted through, it taking several hundred feet of new piping for replacement, apart from the same amount of outside packing or covering, which are both expensive.

This is only one instance of what had to be done, others of the same nature occurring in other sections of the heating system, involving new piping ranging from 7" to 12".

It was also discovered that all the radiators in the dining room and adjoining ones had air valves attached instead of steam valves, which was the reason satisfactory heating had never been obtained. So the incorrect valves were replaced by correct ones.
The steam mains were also leaking causing moisture of the surface of the dining room floor where the children eat. To get at these entailed curving through a 12-inch concrete floor for 30 or 40 feet, naturally a difficult and lengthy operation apart from replacing same.

It was then found the steam mains were only ordinary black piping laying in sand and cinders, the worst possible bed, as the acid in each had eaten through the piping. These mains have now been replaced by genuine galvanized piping laid in tile, preventing another occurrence of such a nature.

Water was also used in the steam tanks, caused by the original construction thereof, and this was conducted by installing new stems and checking the same. The cost of this was $150.

The hot water storage tank was also found to be rusted through by sediment collection in it, and could not be removed. This was replaced by a new 5,000 gallon tank, costing $600, which has proper man hole whereby the tank can be cleaned of sediment and such an occurrence largely prevented.

The work commenced on August 23rd and was not completed until October 8th, entailing 670 hours of labour, 9% of which was at the rate of $1.00 per hour, and the remainder at $.90.

The total cost of labor being $1445, with material costing $600.

From the foregoing outline, which is only part of the work actually carried out, the amount will approximate that extensive, expensive, and urgent repairs were carried out, and it is more than just a thorough and first class job was done, and fair remuneration charged.

The only criticism one might offer is that the Principal once he realized how much more extensive the repair had to be above his estimate, could have handled the department.

It is also my duty to advise you that the plumber, E. P. Oliver, informed me that the entire heating system, also much of the plumbing, at the Mohawk Institute is in poor condition, and liable to cause trouble and inconvenience in the future.

Mr. Oliver states that the original stems have been carried out cheaply by inexpert workmen and its result, in many ways, is much entirely unsuitable. Material and parts used in construction.
Therefore, I would suggest it might be advisable to have an examination and report made covering the entire heating and plumbing plant at the institute, as it would unquestionably be more economical to do once and for all a complete overhaul, rather than constant and expensive patching up here and there.

Your obedient servant,

G. P. Randle

Indian Superintendent.

Dear Sir,

Attention Mr. Hoey - re boiler repairs.

When Mr. Phelan was here his attention was drawn to the condition of the boiler for the main building and at his suggestion I have had the Waterous Co. send a man to estimate the cost of repairs. I have received his report in which he states that it would cost "approximately Seven Hundred & Forty dollars (740.00). We would not guarantee the boiler to be in perfect condition even after these repairs have been made as it has reached the point where different parts will deteriorate fast on account of its age and we believe it would be more satisfactory for you to replace your present boiler with a new one."

At the same time they submitted a tender for a new boiler No. 8522, having a net rating of 11,328 feet radiation for $1978.00. The dead plates and adjustments for the stoker would be extra and to be done by the stoker manufacturers. This would cost approximately $150.00.

I may say that the Waterous representative did not take the measurements of the radiation which we have installed.

I also took the matter up with Mr. K. P. Oliver who does work of this kind for us and on whose advice and work I can place implicit confidence. He, with a heating expert, went over our radiation and reports that we have 4120 feet net which with 500 feet to provide for a possible new chapel would make our total 4620 feet. He, therefore, advises a smaller boiler of the same make with a net rating of 7780 feet which would simply take care of our needs and would be less expensive in the consumption of coal. The cost of this including dead plates would be $1765.00. This is not only a much smaller cost than the Waterous tender but, taking into consideration the difference in the prices of the two boilers, Mr. Oliver's charge for installation is considerably less. I would, therefore, recommend, if it is decided to install a new boiler, to accept the offer of Mr. Oliver. In both cases a Waterous boiler is to be used, the only difference being in size.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir,

Re. boiler.

Major Randle is out of town and as the matter of the boiler should be attended to before cold weather, Mr. Hill came down this morning and has been over the plant and discussed the advisability of repairing the present boiler or putting a new one. The present plant was installed in 1922, I believe, and should have given some longer service.

We agree that it would be waste of money to repair the old one. The cost would be nearly half the price of a new and when done would last only until the old parts wore out. I am told that the present boiler is very extravagant on coal and that a new boiler of the type recommended would save some 50 tons of coal.

We also agree that the tender of Mr. Oliver should be accepted. In discussing the matter of a smaller boiler with Mr. Oliver we learned that his first idea was to recommend a No. 2402 which would have one-eighth (approximately) less net rating but when he talked of it with a heating expert he was of the opinion that the small expenditure of $94.00 extra for the slightly larger size was justified on the ground of efficiency and increased life of the boiler.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Miller,

Re: Mohawk Institute, Brantford, Ontario

In accordance with your instructions, I beg to submit the following report on the heating, plumbing and general conditions of the above noted building.

As mentioned in Dr. McGill's memorandum of Jan. 3rd to our Director, a new Pacific steam boiler has recently been installed in the building and the Principal reported that the efficiency of the new boiler had created serious defects owing to the imperfect installation of the distributing system. This applies particularly to the junior class rooms. As might be expected in an installation of this kind certain changes and adjustments may be necessary before the heating system would work efficiently. I might state that a gravity system of piping is used for the main and upper floors and a non-gravity system for the basement. The pump for the non-gravity system was temporarily out of commission on my arrival which seriously affected the heating of this part of the building until repairs were made.

I found that certain alterations in the piping system to the main and upper floors had already been made including a 3" equilising pipe on the boiler, and as a result the junior class room was being comfortably heated. With below zero temperature outside, a temperature of 68° was noted in this room and at a later date with a cold wind blowing, the room temperature was 74° and at both times the boiler was working at barely two pounds pressure. The remainder of the building was comfortably heated with the exception of the sewing room and after a proper steam trap was installed in the radiator, this room gave no further trouble.

Later after the pump in the basement system was repaired, I found this part was working quite efficiently at present with the air vents on these radiators plugged. I would point out that it may be necessary to install proper steam traps on these radiators, but would suggest that no change be made as long as the basement is being comfortably heated. The cost is about $5.75 each, 30 radiators being in the basement, and the traps are very easily installed. With this exception I see no reason why the building should not be comfortably heated.

In the specifications for the new boiler, the main steam line is to be tapped in such a manner that an indirect water heater will be piped from this main steam line to the hot water tank. I might say that the Chief Engineer of the

T. Miller, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Service,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Waterous Engine Works which Company installed the boiler came out to the Institute during my inspection. He agreed to make certain minor adjustments most of which were carried out before I left on February 11th. With regard to the heater I understood him to say the company would install a larger sized one if necessary, but that he considered a larger one might prove excessively large. On account of the height of the tank and position of the heater, it was decided to install a circulating pump. I was informed the maximum temperature in the tank was 185°. With the small tank and so much water being used for general use during the day, it cannot be expected the heater will keep the water in the tank at this temperature. While a larger sized heater may be necessary, yet in my opinion the Company cannot be expected to do more than this, and also that the Institute officials appear to be expecting too much from this indirect method of heating water.

In the boys' section in the basement, new modern plumbing including basins, toilets and urinals has recently been installed in a workmanlike manner, and I was informed it had been passed by the City of Brantford Plumbing Inspector. In the girls' section part of the wash basins and the toilets are modern, but one set of basins are quite old having only one trap for the 12 basins instead of two traps for each basin. I am informed that the waste pipes to the sewer in the girls' section, which are under the concrete floor, are only two inches in diameter. While these are working alright at present, there is danger of them giving trouble and becoming clogged.

Should trouble develop, new basins and a four inch waste pipe should be installed. As the extent of drain under the floor could only be roughly estimated, I would estimate an approximate amount of $600.00 necessary for this work. In the sick room there is a toilet but no hand basin which would be very convenient and useful and would cost probably $70.00. The toilet on the 3rd floor of the girls' dormitory is partially screened by curtains, and as it is placed in a conspicuous position a partition of a permanent nature would appear advisable.

In both the boys' and girls' sections the plastering generally is in poor condition, many places on the walls and ceilings having been patched. New metal ceilings have been placed on the ceilings in the two classrooms. The third floor of the boys' section is quite modern and in fair condition. In the boys' dormitory on the 2nd floor and sewing room, the plaster ceiling is in very bad condition, being cracked and loose and in danger of falling. The ceiling of the girls' dormitory on the 2nd floor is in slightly better condition. I would suggest metal ceilings if replacements are made rather than trying to make repairs. The girls' dormitory on the third floor is very crowded, and if it was altered to correspond with the boys' dormitory on the third floor, it would provide considerable more room and be much more brighter and comfortable.
With the exception of the third floor of the boys' section the walls and ceilings of the entire girls' and boys' sections from basement to third floor are very dull and dingy and need painting and decorating very badly. In the girls' washroom, the burlap on the walls is loose and torn and would far better be removed and walls painted. For new metal ceilings and painting and decorating, I would estimate an amount of $2,000.00, and to alter the girls' dormitory on the third floor an additional $650.00.

Over the dining room quarters it was noted there is a temporary roof. This is not giving any trouble at present, but will require attention in the next few years. I understand the reason for this roof was that a chapel was proposed to be constructed above the dining room at a later date.

I was informed the electric wiring of the building and barns was inspected by an Ontario Hydro Inspector in the fall of 1936 and any necessary changes required, made at that time. The connecting wires and switch for lighting the stage are of a very temporary nature. Even though not used often, I consider they should be properly installed and would involve very little expense.

There are two small items that should be mentioned on account of the possible risk and needless expense that might be caused. The outside door of the boys' playroom is in a very bad state of repair, panels being cracked and broken. Just inside this door are several steam and water pipes which might easily freeze in extreme cold weather. I would suggest it be replaced with a 2½ inch white pine door. The manual training workshop, which is an old wooden building near the main building, is heated by two coal stoves, and there was no metal covering on the floor, for fire protection, under the stove in use at time of inspection, while under the other there was a very small sized one. This presents a fire hazard especially when ashes are removed and could be remedied at very little expense. I would suggest metal sheets approximately 3' x 4' be placed on the floor under each stove and the cost should be less than $5.00.

The following is a summary of the total estimated cost of repairs I would recommend:

Sir:

A splendid demonstration of your Automatic Fire Alarm system was given at the Mother House of the Grey Nuns of the Cross, at the Corner of Water and Sussex Sts., when a fire occurred on the evening of December 11th, 1934.

The fire originated in the Dust Chute on the basement floor, and the Automatic system operated immediately and set off the siren, which warned the inmates that a fire was in progress. An alarm was then turned in from the street box, which brought apparatus from No. 5 Station, situated a few blocks away.

I am quite certain that had the building not been equipped with an Automatic Fire Alarm System, the property loss would have been heavy. As it happened, the fire was confined to the Dust Chute, the place of origin, and the loss was less than $20,000.

I consider a system of this type an excellent means of detecting a fire in its incipiency, and would highly recommend same to all institutions in this city, with a view of safeguarding the lives of the inmates, and the building proper."

(signed) S. R. Blackler, Chief, Fire Dept.

George H. Carson, Esq.,

Your letter of the 11th inst., to hand. We certainly were lucky. One of the men went into the cupboard off his room, with a cigarette lighter to get some clothes, came out, closing the door behind him.

The Gong sounded the alarm and Smith, the new Superintendent and his son, and the Maid, all of whom were at the time engaged in kalsomining and cleaning the top floor, rushed into the room, and Smith, upon opening the door of the clothes closet, was greeted with flames. They notified the Sault Firemen, and immediately got to work with the chemical fire extinguishers, and managed to put the fire out with five of them. Made sure by taking two of them into the attic.

The fire was out when a few minutes later the Fire Truck from the city arrived. The fire did damage the upper floor of the Firestat, but only just the wire connection which was easily repaired.

THE SYSTEM UNDOUBTEDLY SAVED THE BUILDING, AND HOW MANY LIVES, YOUR GUESS IS AS GOOD AS MINE. THE FIRE CHIEF, AND OTHERS WHO SAW IT, ARE AGREED THAT THE NEW SYSTEM JUSTIFIED ITS INSTALLATION RIGHT THERE."

Reverend Sir:

The Writer, in company with Inspector McGratton, Fire Prevention officer, of the Brantford Fire Department, made a very thorough and complete inspection of your institution, with the end in view of submitting for your most earnest consideration a contract agreement, covering Automatic protection against fire for the above mentioned institution, and the safeguarding of the lives of the occupants from possible destruction by fire, or, suffocation by smoke.

It is a self-evident fact, that the building requires and should have Automatic protection installed for the immediate detection of any fire when it is just commencing. The General construction of the building, with its space between the outer and inner walls, creating what might be termed a fire raceway, basement to attic, with the spreading of the fire between floors as it passes to the attic. Fires of this nature and very hard to control and finally extinguish... If not discovered in time, they generally mean the total destruction of the building, sometimes with appalling loss of life, such as happened in Quebec and other places recently. A night watchman, and fires escapes were of little use, in fact, they were no use at all. WHY? Because the fire was not discovered in time.

Today, with Automatic detection of incipient fires so efficient and reliable, loss of life is caused by three things, namely, Carelessness, neglect, or indifference to the safety of others.... Of course, flash fires, and explosions... Gas, oils, etc., cannot easily be controlled, but, they can in most all cases be prevented if proper precautions are taken in time.

The institute will be very hard to install a protective system in, and will require a great deal of work and care, but, we can assure you, there will be practically no damage done to the walls, ceilings, or floors, and practically all wires will be concealed, with the exception of the attics. You will be pleased, we are quite sure, with the way we install our system.

We cannot of course guarantee price quoted beyond fifteen days from date of contract. Prices are liable to advance rapidly any time.

We are, Sincerely yours,

MOHAWK INSTITUTE

Considerable repairs and improvements are being carried out at the Mohawk Institute, which were certainly urgently necessary. The work is almost entirely being carried out by labour from the reserves which is greatly appreciated as in the past this has not been so.

Supt. welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Sir:

It is the duty of this office to advise you that to complete the painting on the Mohawk Institute as arranged, will take approximately $150.00 more for labour than was estimated.

Since the work commenced I have made a practice of visiting the institute each day to watch closely the progress of the work and until the painters reached the basement they were within the estimated time.

However, the basement which includes the boys and girls playrooms, wash rooms and water closets, is so full of obstructions in the way of multitudinous pipes, radiators and individual clothes closets, that rapid progress is impossible and considerable time has been lost.

Materials will not exceed the estimate and may possibly be thirty or forty dollars less.

The painting, plastering and repairs are completed in all dormitories, school rooms and passage ways, etc., upstairs, except for wall-papering Principal's Office and Officers' room, so the remaining work is confined to playrooms, dining room, kitchen in basement.

After wages are paid at the end of this week the sum estimated ($540.00) for labour for painting and wall-papering will be almost exhausted, and any further sum expended must be provided at additional cost.
Your consideration and instructions on this matter are requested.

Your obedient servant,

E. P. Randle

Indian Superintendent.

Sir:

This office would ask your consideration to authorizing some major and necessary repairs to the implement shed for the farm at the Mohawk Institute.

The shed in question is the usual one of frame with a shingle roof - adjoins the barn and many various implements are stored there when not in use. The building is a little over 80 feet long with an 18 foot rafter.

The main frame work of the sides and ends, and the siding itself is still in good condition. However, after a heavy storm last winter the snow lay so heavily on the roof that it partially collapsed, as a result many of the rafters are broken, and the shingles and sheeting apart from the action of the storm, are rotten with age.

After a personal examination of the shed with the Principal, and a check up on the material required etc., it is found that it will cost between $250.00 and $300.00 to put the shed in proper condition. The labour will, of course be done by the farm foreman and the Indian boys as it is good experience for them.

This office would recommend this work be authorized, as it is understood here that there is some New England Company funds available, and this office would appreciate your reply so the work may be done in good weather.

Yours truly,

Re: Replacing Steam Boiler at Mohawk Institute.

As reported by telephone to the Department today, it is with regret that I have to confirm that it will be necessary to replace the steam boiler at the Mohawk Institute.

As far as can be ascertained, and possibly through inexperience, the member of the staff responsible for operating the boiler, failed to remember to shut a tap after lowering the water, consequently all the water was drained from the system and the boiler heated to such an extent that the local Inspector has declared it entirely unfit for further service.

This boiler was installed in 1938 and with it was installed a Morrison type Low Water Cut-off, which, on the water becoming low, should have cut out the stoker, which would then have prevented the overheating which occurred, but apparently for some unexplained reason, this cut-off did not work.

The Department would appreciate that under present conditions with high wages prevailing everywhere, it is no longer possible to secure, at the rate of wages paid at the Mohawk Institute, the more experienced employees. Consequently the employee assigned to the duty of operating the boiler, was not as experienced or efficient as has been employed in the past, and in view of these circumstances the Principal must to some extent be absolved from the responsibility. However, apart from the circumstances just outlined, the Department will appreciate the immediate necessity is to obtain a new boiler, as of course with the approach of cold weather it is urgently necessary for the health and comfort of the many officers and children housed in this building, for the building to be heated.

This office was in touch with Waterous Limited of this city today, as they were the firm who supplied us with the present boiler, and they advised that they have a boiler suitable for our use at

-over
the present time. They could not quote a price today but said that in any event the price would be f.o.b. their yards, as at the present time they were not in a position to install the boiler, and suggested we secure one of the experienced local men to do the installing.

Enquiries were also made of the Foster Wheeler Company in St.Catharines, and was advised it would be three or four weeks before they could possibly supply us with the required boiler.

This office trusts the Department will appreciate the urgency of this matter, particularly in regard to the health of the many children who might suffer through being housed in a chilly building, and trust that everything possible will be done to secure the immediate installation of the new boiler.

Lt.Col.E.P.Randle, Indian Superintendent.

I have your letter of the 18th instant,
with reference to the steam boiler at the Mohawk
Institute.

I note that the boiler will have to be
replaced and, as this is a very urgent matter, in
order to protect the health of the children, you may
authorize the Principal to secure a boiler from the
Waterous Company. The boiler purchased in 1936 cost
$2075. Under separate cover the Principal is being
forwarded a cheque for $500 from New England Company
funds in order that he may pay for the boiler when it
is installed.

I have given your letter very careful
consideration and you should inform the Principal
that the Department takes a very serious view of
the whole matter. I feel that it is evident that
very little attention is being given to the
mechanical plant, as otherwise the person in charge
of the boiler would have made certain that the cut-
off was working properly.

The whole matter is so serious and
reflects so adversely on the management that I feel
it is necessary to investigate the matter fully and
I have instructed Mr. Phelan to visit the Mohawk
Institute on Friday, October 27. I trust that you will find it possible to accompany him to the school, at which time the Principal and the person in charge of the boiler should be interviewed and all the facts obtained. Mr. Phelan will report to me on his return.

FOR FOURTH CLASS

MATHEMATICS:

A knowledge of arithmetic sufficient to solve any simple problem involving division and multiplication.

BOILERS:

A general knowledge of all types of boilers, dealing particularly with stationary fire tube and water tube type; a knowledge of how and where boilers are stayed; how and where tubes are fastened in place; where manholes and handholds are placed and how plates are kept in place; a thorough knowledge of the care and upkeep of safety valves, water columns, water glasses, steam gauges, blow-off valves, non-return valves, fusible plugs, etc., together with a knowledge of the cleaning of boilers and the general upkeep of brick work, grates, etc.

INJECTORS:

A thorough working knowledge of the construction, care and upkeep of injectors, together with a knowledge of how they are connected up, and the piping and valves that should be used in connection with them; a knowledge of the conditions under which injectors will operate.

PUMPS:

A general knowledge of the different types of pumps (particularly boiler feed), both centrifugal and reciprocating.

Method by which condensate is returned to boilers in heating systems.

ENGINES:

A working knowledge of the care and operation of the plain slide valve engine.

FEED WATER APPARATUS:

A knowledge of the different apparatus and methods of heating feed water for boilers.

COMBUSTION:

A practical knowledge of combustion; a practical knowledge of hand-firing and operation of mechanical underfeed and overfeed stokers and oil burning furnaces.
PIPELINE:

A general knowledge of piping and valves required in a plant; a knowledge of the methods and care required in "Cutting in" and "Cutting out" boiler and pipe lines.

MISCELLANEOUS:

A knowledge sufficient to give an intelligent answer to any question relating to the uses, care and operation of throttle valves, non-return valves, steam separators, steam traps, expansion joints, reducing valves, sight feed lubricators, pump lubricators, or any other apparatus commonly used in an ordinary steam plant.

ELECTRICITY AND REFRIGERATION:

A practical knowledge of the care and operation of electrical and refrigeration machinery.

Reverend Sir:

Mr. Phelan has reported to me regarding the boiler at the Mohawk Institute. The Department takes a very serious view of what has happened, as the only conclusion that can be reached is that our equipment is not receiving the attention that it deserves.

I understand that you intend to replace Mr. Bricker, the present engineer and handy man, by another person. Before making final arrangements with this man you should have him interviewed by our Superintendent, Colonel Randle. He will be in a position to decide if the man can be employed.

Mr. Phelan interviewed the officials of the Boiler Inspection Branch of the Department of Labour in Toronto and, in the interests of all parties concerned, it is considered that a person holding at least fourth class papers should be engaged. If it is not possible to secure a person with these papers, whoever is employed should be hired on the understanding that he will immediately endeavour to obtain such qualifications and, failing his ability to do so, the position will have to be offered to somebody else.

You will also be expected to issue very specific instructions regarding the maintenance of all the heating equipment and you should take care that the person in charge of the furnace during the day personally transfers his duties to the one who is taking charge for the night.

Rev. H.W. Snell,
Principal,
Mohawk Institute,
Brantford, Ont.
Memorandum:

Acting on your instruction I visited the Mohawk Institute on October 27, accompanied by Indian Superintendent Randle.

Colonel Randle's letter of October 19 outlined what had happened. In interviewing the Principal, Reverend Mr. Snell, it was found that acting on the instructions of the man who is in charge of the furnace one of the boys lowered the water in the boiler. Instead of simply lowering the water he left the tap open and went on to perform other duties and no one checked the matter. About 9:30 in the evening the building became cold and the stoker was started without anyone ascertaining if there was water in the boiler. As the pipes did not heat the Principal again visited the boiler room and found the boiler ruined due to the fact that there was no water in it and the stoker had been running for over an hour.

From conversation with the Principal it appears that the so-called engineer, the boys' master and even the Principal operate the stoker whenever they feel more heat is required. I pointed out to the Principal that this was a very careless habit and issued instructions that in future the boiler should be operated by one or two persons and that when anyone was taking charge of the boiler he should take over from the one who had been handling it for the previous period. The Principal stated that he had engaged another man whom he considered qualified. We discussed this person's qualifications and it is possible that he will be an improvement on the man who has been employed. However, I believe that it is advisable to instruct Colonel Randle to interview this man and make certain that he is capable.

Another matter that arose during the course of our discussion was the fact that one of the cottages on the school property is occupied by a former member of the staff who secured other work some months ago. I instructed the Principal that this man should be requested to vacate this building at the earliest possible date, in order that we would have it available in the event of securing an engineer who would require accommodation.

As previously instructed, Superintendent Randle had made arrangements with the Watrous Engine Company to secure a new boiler and Colonel Randle and I again
interviewed the officials of the Matrou Company and they stated that the boiler was available at any time. It will be impossible to repair the present boiler and it is only suitable for sale as scrap iron. Colonel Randle has arranged with the firm to dismantle the boiler and he has also arranged with another firm to install a new boiler. It is hoped to have the new boiler installed during the week of October 30. It is fortunate that the weather was comparatively mild; otherwise, the pupils and the staff would have suffered from the cold, as there was no heat in the building.

Following my visit to Brantford I interviewed Mr. Briggs, Chief Inspector of the Boiler Inspection Branch of the Department of Labour in Toronto. While the low pressure boiler we operate at Mohawk does not actually require a person holding a certificate, at the same time it would be preferable to have such a person, due to the fact that the hot water boiler is a high pressure one. In conversation with Mr. Briggs he suggested that in the best interests of all parties concerned it would be preferable to secure a person holding at least fourth class papers. If the person engaged does not hold such papers, arrangements can be made to have him examined by the Board of Examiners of the Boiler Inspection Branch in Toronto.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, November 2, 1944.

Dear Colonel Randle:

I have before me a report dated October 30, submitted to me by Mr. Phelan, immediately following his inspection of the Mohawk Institute on October 27.

It is unnecessary to state that I have found the subject matter of this report and the information contained therein very disturbing. Despite the critical period in which we are living and the difficulty experienced by residential school principals in securing the help necessary to operate these institutions efficiently, I nevertheless find it difficult to understand the carelessness that resulted in the destruction of the boiler at the school. This destruction was, no doubt, due in part to the fact that the so-called engineer, the boys' master and even the Principal himself were responsible from time to time for the supervision of the boiler and the operation of the stoker. Dual or triple control in the operation of a boiler inevitably leads to disaster.

Ordinarily, the destruction of the boiler would justify us in asking the Principal for his resignation. You are probably aware, however, that it was our intention to ask Mr. Snell for his resignation at the close of the present academic year and to completely reorganize the school at that time. In this connection I may state that I made arrangements for an interview with Canon Dixon at Toronto during the week ending November 18. In view of these circumstances, I feel that perhaps it would be measurably satisfactory to the Minister if we had an assurance from you that you would, despite the limited time at your disposal, reach an agreement with the Principal, whereby he would consult you in respect to the qualifications of

Lt.- Col. E. F. Randle,
Indian Superintendent,
Brantford, Ont.
the members of his staff, particularly the men in charge of farming operations and the man in charge of the boiler. You should discuss this suggestion with Mr. Snell at your office immediately following the receipt of this letter and let me know, in due course, just what arrangement you have been able to reach with him.

One regrettable feature of this whole matter is the fact that we are taking money to replace this boiler from funds contributed by the people of England - people who have never hesitated, during the war period, to send forward this contribution, despite the appalling losses that they themselves have sustained. I feel sure that even the Principal will be somewhat impressed by this thought.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

This will acknowledge your 32-0-5 of the 2nd instant and the copy of your letter to the principal of the Mohawk Institute both in connection with the installation of the new boiler.

Mr. Snell has been interviewed and concurs in the arrangement whereby any future appointments to his staff are made with the knowledge and approval of myself.

With regard to Mr. Earl Edwards, new boys' master, and responsible for the boiler and water heater, I have concurred in his appointment, after securing information locally and personally interviewing him.

The local firm he worked for for years give him an excellent report, and he gave up his position on medical advice, as he was operating a power press and his doctor informed him he would be wise to live at such work.

As far as I am concerned, he is only 30 years old, so should have many useful years ahead - and appears alert and intelligent - and should with experience be capable in every way of filling his position at the Mohawk Institute well.

Arrangements are being made for him to obtain his papers to qualify for the operation and maintenance of the boiler - and the importance and necessity of careful attention to those duties have been impressed upon him.

Re FIRE INSURANCE - MOHAWK INSTITUTE.

The three years Policy arranged with the Western Union Assurance on the above property expired last month, and, in accordance with our previous correspondence and the terms of the suggested new Lease, we have arranged for this insurance to be renewed for a further three years on the understanding that same shall be transferred into the name of the Lessee when the final arrangements for the continuance of the Mohawk Institute have been arrived at.

We understand that the Principal, the Rev. H. Snell, had an interview with the Superintendent of Agencies to the Western Assurance Company, Toronto, and that the latter gentleman inspected the premises prior to issuing the new Policy which, as you are no doubt aware, gives this Company a total insurance value of £162,525.--

Our Agents here advise us that the present replacement cost of buildings in Canada stands at something like £5 more than before the war, and suggest that we consider increasing the amount of cover accordingly, particularly in the case of those items of the Policies which are subject to 80% co-insurance clause requiring the amount of insurance to be not less than 80% of the full value, although in any case insurance for the full value is advisable as a matter of precaution.

In view of the fact that the insurance costs will be transferred from this Company and borne by the Lessees on your side upon the completion of the Lease, we should be glad if you

Ottawa, July 14, 1945.

MEMORANDUM

In addition to interviewing the applicants for the position of Principal of the Mohawk Institute, I carefully inspected the buildings during my trip to Brantford on July 6 and 7. While visiting the school I was accompanied by Indian Superintendent Randle and we had several discussions, both with the Principal, Mr. Snell, and with the Matron, Mrs. Snell.

Attached to this memorandum is an inventory of the government property on hand at the Mohawk Institute on July 7, 1945. I wish to bring the following matters to your attention:

1. All the farm machinery is in serviceable condition and has received careful attention by the farmer; when not in use, it is stored at all times in sheds for the purpose.

2. We found that while there is a reasonably adequate quantity of clothing on hand for the girls, the supply of clothing for the boys for the coming academic year, including shoes and rubbers, is very limited, and a considerable quantity of the articles mentioned will have to be purchased before September 1.

3. Generally speaking, the school is in reasonably good condition, although some of the rooms require painting. The Principal assured us that the plumbing and heating were now perfectly satisfactory and there should not be any heavy expenditure required in the immediate future.

The south side of the roof of the main barn requires immediate repairs in order to prevent future possible damage. The repairs required should not involve any heavy expenditure.

4. When Mr. Snell became Principal he brought his own car. Later this car was turned in when purchasing a new car. At that time the turn-in value of the car owned by Mr. Snell was $1,000.00. The car at present owned has only a current value of $600.00. Mr. Snell felt that he should be allowed to take this old car, in view of the fact that he had purchased a new car. I thought this was reasonable and approved of such action. As a matter of fact, he has always carried the license of the car in his own name. When the new Principal is appointed the question will arise about
the purchase of a car for him and I feel that we should purchase the car outright and have it licensed in the name of the School.

6. The truck that we purchased several years ago was completely worn out about 8 or 9 months ago and was sold by the Principal for $150.00—which amount Indian Superintendent Randle considered reasonable. The school actually needs a small truck for carrying garden produce and the greenhouse plants, etc., to the Brantford market. Early consideration should be given to the purchase of this vehicle.

7. I also attach to this report a statement prepared by Mr. Bertha, Departmental Auditor, with reference to the farming operations for the fiscal years 1943-44 and 1944-45. Colonel Randle and I reviewed these and the former considered them reasonably satisfactory, but he feels that a new principal could make a better showing by keeping a stricter supervision on the operations of the farm and greenhouse. The farmer, Mr. Haworth, has been in our employ for several years and has an excellent knowledge of farming and splendid working. As stated above, the machinery is kept in excellent condition and the farming operations are carried out efficiently. However, there is no doubt that if the Principal gave more personal attention to this phase of the school's work, it would be an encouragement both to the farmer and the gardener to put forth extra effort.

8. In visiting the dormitories it was found that practically all the mattresses are in very poor condition, and I strongly recommend that before the school reopens in September new mattresses be purchased. There is approximately $4,500.00 still remaining in the Trust Fund where we deposited the payments made by the New England Company, and when the new principal is appointed, I suggest that we allow him funds from this account to purchase the new clothing and also use part of this fund for the purchase of mattresses and for other repairs and purchases previously mentioned.

As you are aware, Reverend Mr. Snell and Mrs. Snell have been instructed to vacate the building on July 31, 1945.

Mrs. Smith, who has been acting as assistant matron, is willing to stay until September 1, at which time she will have to be replaced, as she does not wish to return to the school.

Mrs. Thorpe is only acting temporarily as senior dietitian and another appointment will have to be made to this position by September 1.

With the exception of the positions mentioned above, all other members of the staff have intimated that they are willing to remain.

By an old agreement between the New England Company and Dr. R. F. Palmer, of Brantford, the latter has been the medical officer for the school for a great many years. He has been allowed only $100.00 a year—which amount has been paid from school funds—for his services. In case of serious illness, pupils are either sent to the Lady Willingdon Hospital on the Reserve or placed in the Brantford City Hospital. In the latter case, accounts are rendered to this Board for payment. Dr. Palmer is advancing in age and has not enjoyed good health and, when illness occurs, it is frequently impossible to obtain his services. I feel that the medical services at this school should be handled by our Medical Division and the cost of doctor's services should be paid from the Medical Appropriation, in the same manner as at other Indian residential schools. It seems to me proper to make this change immediately; as, from the information I received, it is evident that Dr. Palmer regards the Mohawk Institute as one of his special duties and when he was in good health he visited the school at every possible opportunity.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Probe Ordered Into Affairs Of Indian School

Brantford, Feb. 22 (CP).—An inspector from the Indian Affairs Department at Ottawa will arrive here early next week to conduct "a full investigation" into the alleged lack of sufficient clothing and educational facilities for Indian children attending the Mohawk Institute. It was announced today by W. Ross MacDonald, Liberal member of Parliament for Brantford.

The Brantford Women's Council, in a report following an inspection of the school, stated that a "division of authority" in administration caused conditions that required immediate investigation at the boys' school.

The report, urging increased federal grants, was presented at a meeting yesterday attended by Mr MacDonald and Archdeacon A. L. G. Clarke of Grace Anglican Church.

Mr. MacDonald said today he had telephoned the information to R. A. Hoey, director of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, who requested immediate action. Mr. Hoey told an inspector would make a full investigation and consult with members of the Women's Council who had made the report.

It was pointed out that grants from the New England Missionary Society in Great Britain, which owns the school lands and buildings, were suspended following the outbreak of war.

The local Women's Council recommended in their report that more teachers be provided, classroom furniture be increased, and a recreational room, gymnasium, and library be added, and that Government grants for upkeep of both children and school be increased.

Ottawa, Feb. 22 (CP).—R. A. Hoey, director of Indian Affairs, said today administrative readjustments were being made at the Mohawk Institute in Brantford, following withdrawal of an annual contribution for its upkeep by the New England Missionary Society.

He did not elaborate, but said a representative of his department would go to Brantford to inquire into alleged lack of sufficient clothing and educational facilities for Indian children attending the institute.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that I made an inspection recently of the Mohawk Institute for the purpose of ascertaining the adequacy of exit facilities and locating any fire hazards that might be in the buildings.

I wish at this time to extend to you my sincere thanks for your kindness and courtesy in escorting me through the buildings. I can assure you that this was greatly appreciated.

This inspection revealed that there are numerous conditions that not only constitute a fire hazard but also several that are contrary to the safety regulations for safe egress for the pupils in the event of fire. During the past few years I have submitted reports to the Principal of this school pointing out several hazards and also recommending safeguards for safe exit, but apparently these reports have either been ignored or filed without action. I am very pleased to state, however, that after having contacted Col. Handle, he, as well as yourself have assured me of every co-operation to bring this school up to a reasonable standard of safety.

The electric wiring in quite a number of places is not in good condition, the horse barn has bare spots in numerous places, many circuits are overloaded, an electric washing machine is being used from an old brass wall fixture, several storerooms have apparently been wired by amateurs, and the wiring in the dispensary needs replacing; however, I have referred these conditions to the Hydro Electric Comm. Inspector who, I think should go over the entire wiring and have it brought up to a safe condition. No doubt you will get a report from him on these conditions.

The attic and the upstairs part of the work shop was found to be badly cluttered with old wood, broken furniture and almost every type of article. In previous reports I have recommended that these places be gone over and all useless material removed. This material has been accumulating for quite some time, and if a fire was to start in either of these places it would be very difficult to subdue owing to the highly flammable material. These should be given a thorough house-cleaning as soon as possible.
W.J. Zimmerman, Esq. Contd.

The mortar has become loose in some of the bricks in the fireplace in the principal's apartment; this fireplace should not be used unless this is repaired.

A dumb waiter was found extending from the basement up through the building; this is constructed of wood. In the event of fire an open flue such as this would allow it to spread from one floor to another very rapidly. As I have been informed that this is rarely used I would recommend that it be removed and the openings in the floors filled in.

A two burner electric hot plate set up on a portable table was in the kitchen of the Principal's apartment. It appears that this plate has to be utilized in order to get sufficient cooking space in this kitchen. This set-up is very dangerous and should be removed. A stove of sufficient size should be provided to take care of the cooking in this area.

In quite a number of rooms small areas of plaster has fallen leaving wooden lath exposed; this should be repaired, as plaster will hold back fire for some time, whereas, without such protection fire can easily spread to concealed areas where it would spread very rapidly and be hard to subdue.

A cupboard used for storage of canned goods partially blocks the corridor on the second floor. Shelf space should be provided in one of the storage rooms and this cupboard should be removed. A small wooden cupboard has been erected in the corner just outside the staff's dining room; this is used for storage of mops and cleaning material and should also be removed. The storage of cleaning mops and material should be in metal cupboards.

Several places throughout the building open containers are used for waste papers; closed metal containers should be provided for this purpose.

The valve which controls the gas for the oven of the cook stove was leaking very badly; this is exceptionally dangerous and should be repaired immediately.
A row of old wooden boxes, used as private lockers for the girls, badly dilapidated, was found on the floor or the girls playroom. Most of these lockers had considerable refuse in them. These should be removed, and if it is necessary to have private lockers, metal ones should be provided.

In various places in the basement I could steam pipes wrapped with newspaper; this is definitely a serious menace as steam pipes will ignite wood so that it should take very little time for them to ignite paper. These wrappings should be removed immediately and proper asbestos coverings used.

An old stove is set up in the woodshop with a long lay of pipe passing through two wooden partitions to the chimney. A setup like this is always dangerous and quite often causes serious fires. It would be much better if this building could be heated with steam.

A long extension light fastened on nails was found in the basement of the greenhouse. If a light is needed in the coal storage it should be put in properly and if an extension light is needed a wall receptacle should be provided and the light disconnected when not in use.

I found that when some of the boys are sitting on a bench by the chimney in the greenhouse they use sharp instruments and pick the mortar out of the chimney. There are several holes quite deep. This chimney should be pointed up and I would suggest that it be covered with metal to prevent this destruction.

The alarm box system that is in the school was found to be inadequate. There are boxes on each floor of the girls part and on the main and second floor of the boys part, and one in the main hall of the building. I found only one bell situated in the main hall; this system is electrically controlled. On making a test of the system I found that the bell could not be heard in either the boys or the girls dormitories, therefore, it would be of little use in the time that it was needed. I made a test of every box and several did not work at all. In view of the above conditions I would recommend that an entire new system be installed that would awaken every person in the building in the event of fire or an emergency. There are various types of systems in several institutions in our
W.J. Zimmerman Esq.

City and I would like for you and any other official whom you would like to take with you see these alarm systems and hear their operation. I might say that I would be pleased to go with you at your convenience.

The exit facilities were also found to be inadequate and contrary to safety regulations. A By-Law, No. 2916, recently passed by the Corporation of the City of Bradford to govern all Public Halls, Schools, Churches and all places where there are crowds assembled, require all exit doors to open outwardly, be equipped with panic type hardware and be lighted with illuminated exit signs. I found the main entrance door, classroom doors, dining room doors, exit door from the sewing room, in fact practically all the doors except those on the fire escape, opening inwardly, equipped with various types of locks and no exit signs. I could recommend that immediate steps be taken to have all exits comply with this by-law as I feel that if a fire was to occur at night under the present set-up, that there could very easily be serious loss of life.

For several years we have been recommending that a proper fire drill be organized in this school, but apparently this has also been neglected. The fire drill system in our schools has proven that you have good control of the children by alarm signals. It is very essential that this be started as soon as possible, but, I realize it would be very difficult to do without proper alarm signals. This matter should be of the first to be looked after.

In regard to fire protection— I found that two standpipes, one each end of the building with hose on each floor and quite a number of extinguishers have been provided. I found that two lines of hose has become full of holes and was of no use, this should be replaced with rubber lined 1½ inch hose and I would suggest that shut-off nozzles be provided. Two of the valves were broken and either need replacing or repairing. The other hose should be taken down and cleaned and cut back and recoupled, I would be pleased to assist in this if you so desire. The soda and acid extinguishers have been recharged on April 25, 1945,
these will need recharging again next month. The vapourizing type of extinguishers in the kitchen and dining room were not working and appear to be beyond repair, and I would recommend that the two vapourising type, one in the attic and one in your apartment be moved to the kitchen and dining room and two new soda acid type be provided in their place. Most of the extinguishers were found sitting on the floor, these should be hung up with the top not over 5 feet from the floor. When this protection is arranged to give the most protection possible I would recommend that an organisation be set-up among the staff as a volunteer fire brigade so that everyone would know what to do in case of fire and be able to operate the protection that is provided. This equipment will not operate automatically and is only efficient if operated intelligently. I would be willing to co-operate in this set-up by helping to organise and instruct on the proper use of the equipment if you so desire to do so.

Open grates, some broken were found in the classrooms, these apparently were at one time used for ventilating. These places are not only a catch-all for papers and other things that the pupils poke in them but also help to create a draft and allow fire to spread. These should be closed up tightly with incombustible material.

Owing to the fact that there are a number of frame buildings in this institution I have instructed that there must be no smoking in the barns and work-shop. I have given Mr. Howarth "NO SMOKING" signs to erect in these places.

In submitting these recommendations, we do so, with the thought of making this institution and the pupils in it as safe as possible. If there are any recommendations that you are not clear on I would be pleased to go into detail with you at any time. I would appreciate it if you would let me know what action is being taken on these recommendations and the approximate time it will take to have them completed.

Yours truly,

Signed. M.C. Rathbun,
Fire Inspector.
Ottawa, March 14, 1946.

Dear Colonel Randle:

I have a letter from Rev. Mr. Zimmerman, dated the 13th instant, enclosing a copy of the Fire Inspector's report on the Mohawk Institute. I note from Mr. Zimmerman's letter that he has given you a copy of the report and I also note from the Fire Inspector's letter that he has been in touch with you.

I realize that you are busy, but I presume you will find time to discuss the whole report with Mr. Zimmerman. A number of the matters mentioned by the Fire Inspector can be handled by the school staff. I have already approved local purchase of the fire hose required to replace the hose that is now useless. If funds on hand will permit you looking after some of the other repairs required to meet the Inspector's wishes, approval is granted for such action. However, if additional funds are needed, you might let me know the approximate amount required.

I wish you would tell Mr. Zimmerman that I have received his letter and that I hope the matters that can be handled by the staff will receive immediate attention.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

This office under the late Mr. Rev. Mr. Smith has been unable to get a copy of the Fire Inspector's report on the fire at the Indian Institute, in various locations in the province of Ontario.

One of the major fire hazards on local reserves is the neglect by the Principal, who is not so aware of the fire hazards present.

The two fires of last year, in London, Ont., and in Toronto, Ont., have again been set by the same person who was responsible for the two new ones purchased.

Now, the only real aspects of the report are the condition of the fire alarm system and the condition of the building.

Fortunately, we will not have any heavy expenditure, but no doubt the Department will take the necessary steps to ensure safety and the safety of the students.

April 10th 1946

Rev. W.J. Zimmerman  
Principal, Mohawk Institute  
Brantford, Ont.

Dear Sir:

After having accompanied you and Col. Randle to several institutions to hear various types of fire alarms so that you could get an idea of the type that would be most suitable for the Mohawk Institute, I feel that the best type would be the automatic alarm signal system that would give an alarm automatically in the event of fire in any part of the building. However, in the event that these are not available at the present time, the hooter system, such as was demonstrated at the Ontario School For The Blind would certainly arouse the pupils when the alarm was pulled in the event of fire. In my opinion, in order to make this efficient, it would be necessary to have a hooter in each dormitory and all the old boxes replaced with new ones and an additional box put in, in the boys dormitory on the third floor. Part of your old system could be used for this set-up. I would also recommend that the alarm system be connected to the Fire Station so that a bell would ring in the Station if the alarm was turned in at the Institution. This would bring assistance much sooner than if the alarm had to be telephoned to the Fire Station.

No provision has been made to light the area around the fire escapes at the rear of the building and as it is very necessary for these escapes to be lighted so that the pupils will have no difficulty in making free egress I would recommend that immediate steps be taken to provide lights over these escapes so that they are fully lighted the entire night.

Trusting that these matters will receive your prompt attention.

Yours Truly,

H.C. Hutchison  
Fire Inspector.

Dear Colonel Neary:

The electric inspector is prepared to inspect the wiring in the main building provided the Department will give him the authority. Various men have expressed grave concern regarding the wiring. I feel that to call in an inspector would enable the department to ascertain the true facts. The fee is $2.00. In case of a fire having its origin in faulty wiring the administration would be held liable. The city fire inspectors have requested already such an inspection. I am asking for the Department's permission to call in Inspector Moat. I have already forwarded a copy of the fire inspector's report.

During my time at the school the boilers have not been inspected. The law calls for a maintenance man with fourth class papers. The upright boiler which we use is high pressure. The pressure carried is 50 pounds. The information which I have is that to operate a high pressure boiler one must have papers. Do you wish me to have the boilers inspected?

James Dunn, the chief engineer at Cocksutts, has been very generous with his time and talent in the past. He has given me splendid advice on many occasions. He tells me that the boiler in the greenhouse is too small. We are securing the firm's estimation of the capacity of the present boiler and the amount of radiation required by our greenhouse. I believe that certain things can be done to increase the present efficiency of the boiler now in use.
During cold weather for years the boiler has been hardly capable of excluding the frost from the West section. Mr. Coates was wondering if there are any boilers at Mount Elgin that are not now promised that could be used in the greenhouse? We would not wish them if they are unsuitable. Mr Dunn lectures to the men who take the firemen's course here at the Collegiate. Mr. Coates tells me that a small pump would help to return the water to the boiler. Also the returns are not large enough.

The truck appeared to be most desirable. The condition for example of the seats was perfect. As far as we were able to judge the truck appeared not to have been abused. The engine was started by the man and sounded quite good. We shall be most happy to receive it.

Mrs. Fry has 87 children in her room. We are certainly looking forward to those buildings when we can secure the manual training teacher. You will be glad to know that many books are arriving. I appreciate them very much.

As a matter of record I should like to let you know that certain men from Toronto asked Mr. Hawarth to locate certain city sewage outlets in connection with the proposed sewage disposal plant for the city. I have already informed Colonel Randle. These outlets are near the Chapel on Indian Property.

The yield of the potatoes in the field was not as good as we had hoped. I feel that the low production was largely due to lack of cultivation. Once again may I stress the need of the tractor for the hoe crop. I cannot see the wisdom of spending money on potato seed and not receiving an adequate return. It is bad business. The garden potatoes yielded splendidly and they were well worked.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Colonel Beary:

Your letter re-meat from Golden Lake has been received. I do hope that the extremely warm weather will not spoil the meat since it has been on the road one week. I have asked the C.N.R. to inform me at once the minute the meat arrives. I do hope it does not spoil.

You will be glad to know that our stoves have arrived. Installation will be completed tomorrow. We used one of them last evening and we were delighted with its service. I must express to the Department our appreciation. What do you desire that I do with the discarded stoves?

Mr. Phelan has never said what I am to do with the washer which we removed from the laundry. I have placed the washer outside awaiting instructions from Ottawa.

Cockshutt's Brantford agent called at the school last week and stated that out of his 1947 quota of tractors he could make available to the Institute a Roe-Crop 70 Tractor with cultivator and two furrow plough. It is astonishing to learn that a farm with 275 acres does not possess its own plough. The one that has been used is owned by Cockshutts. Unfortunately, it has a wide bottom.
My maintenance man has nearly filled in the head of the stairway. Col. Randle gave me a glass door from the camp. The cost will be very small since there is no labour costs.

I have heard nothing further regarding the music teacher from the Reservation. Am I to consider the matter closed for next term? I have said nothing to the Colonel.

The Dominion W.A. of the Anglican Church has sent in some very fine clothes. We have been given about 300 blankets which will not cost me anything. The local Rotary Club has offered to give the children on Christmas Day a turkey dinner. Each child is also given a present. Eight of the boys have joined the naval cadets. They are enjoying the work extremely well. I find that many people are becoming very interested in the school.

I am curious to know what happened when the leaders of Indian work from the three churches met Mr. Hoey on the 27 of November. Has the outcome of that meeting been made public. Has Mr. Hoey said anything further about the grant for the Mohawk Institute?

I have not been able to make any further plans for Mr. Anderson since I do not know when the buildings are going to arrive. The result is that the teacher situation is somewhat up in the air. I turned back two more children today.

Yours sincerely,

With reference to your File 32-0-5 (WT 1) of the 27th of May, this office is now enclosing the quotation of Savory Electric to carry out the work necessary at the Mohawk Institute, as requested in the Electrical Inspector's report of January 9th 1947, including main building, greenhouses and horse stable.

You will note the total amount is higher than the previous offer from the United Electric, though based somewhat differently and prices for everything have moved up since February.

United Electric considered 206 new outlets were necessary, while Savory estimates only 50. Savory includes replacing defective wiring in all buildings, additional lighting and outlets under one heading, whereas United Electric have it under two headings.

United Electric suggest $500.00 be set aside for new fixtures, whereas Savory Electric does not include them in their estimate, but suggest we use some we have at the former military camp. You will appreciate it is only some fixtures that will have to be changed, as many of the present ones are quite suitable.

You will appreciate it is most difficult for any layman to fully understand such a complicated job as rewiring an old and large building such as the Mohawk Institute is, - and even the firms quoting have some unknown factors ahead of them in getting approaches through walls, floors and partitions.

The Savory Electric are a long established and reliable firm, much used by the local Hydro people, - while the United Electric are a new organization whose management we understand has changed more than once, which may mean they do not know the business too well.

This office favours the Savory Electric, in spite of what appears a higher quotation (as some of this can be accounted for by increasing wages and material costs), and Mr. Savory says if the Department feel the estimate is too high, his Company will do the job at cost plus 15%. He would submit all invoices for material; labour at the moment is $1.35 per hour, - and add 15%.
This Company are doing a very large job here for Eaton's Store on this same basis.

May your instructions on this work be received at an early date, as material is hard to obtain, and contractors must prepare ahead. The Savory Electric could do considerable work immediately, as they have material on hand, - but might not complete the entire job at once.

The question now arises as to what work further the Government are prepared to authorize and provide funds for this year.

The part used as a school-room will naturally have to be equipped with blackboards, seats, teacher's desk and chair, and you have already been requested to "see if something can be done."

The whole building should be painted inside and out. Similar building is needed at the Reserve in Moosonee to house about 150 Indians, a cost of two cents per foot. Cost of the cost of paint, $200.00 for building for labour and about $70.00 for building for rent.

We could, of course, just rent it again, but we would have to pay the rent for another year, and build of course, losing all the use for another year.

Then as you know, the outside walls are only covered with bark, which soon gets wet and looks bad until the new covering is put on, which costs a considerable amount. To replace them costs $2.00 per square foot, which means a great deal of expense. Before you get into the new building, this has to be replaced and covered with bark.

Also a small area near by is needed for a stable built for horses and stables. The cost of stable is not included, though it will need to be done. Also there can be a pole stage built to provide for lighting over the yard.

Finally, and a necessity, a pump for water and heating water for the report station. To inform the wind vane used by the wind in the house.
will not pass inspection, as it is not raised in cable or like, but just loose wire running above the ceiling.

Of course, we also put traps to assist the wiring of the buildings, and electricians advise that even if it would pass inspection certain changes would be necessary for the new purpose the building was built to be used for, and it is easier to put in a new system. In ordinary cases, of course, he secured.

This office would appreciate your early reply, so that we can see these changes and improvements can be carried out, and you will appreciate the wiring should be done first before painting is commenced.

The lighting for the recreation room could be quite simple, but the school-room would need a roof so some roofing work.

There is no other matter which requires our consideration at this time except making up forms for the records for this. Memorandum:

COLONEL

Re: Mohawk Institute.

Accompanied by Indian Superintendent Randle I visited the above mentioned school on November 14th, 1947. I reviewed with the principal the situation that has arisen in connection with the green house. At one time this particular activity probably operated at a profit but during the last few years the operation of it has barely covered expenses. This condition is due partly to the fact that there are a large number of privately operated green houses in Brantford and the immediate vicinity and partly to the fact that it seems impossible to secure a qualified man who can operate the green house at a profit.

At the present time the roof of this building is in very bad condition as nearly half of it should have new glass. We went through the green house and there is practically nothing growing in it now.

From the point of view of training the boys, both Col. Randle and myself feel that its continued operation is unnecessary. The boys receive adequate training in both general agriculture and gardening from Mr. Haworth. Even though we fixed the roof it would require approximately $500. to heat this building during the winter months.

Taking everything into consideration, both Col. Randle and myself feel that the operation of the green house should be discontinued and the building demolished using the materials that may be salvaged for repairs around the school or at the day schools on the Six Nations Reserve.

We discussed this matter fully with Rev. Mr. Zimmerman and he agreed that the operation of the green house should be discontinued. With the above in mind, I submit the letter hereunder addressed to Lt.-Col. Randle.

Philip Phelan - Chief, Train'n D.
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, November 25, 1947.

Dear Mr. Cochrane:

One of our officials recently inspected the Mohawk Institute at Brantford, Ontario. He was accompanied on that occasion by the Indian Superintendent, Lt.-Colonel E.P. Randle.

For many years past a greenhouse has been operated by this school. The produce raised has been sold and any net profit has been retained by the school management to meet expenses.

During the last few years it has been practically impossible to operate it at a profit. This condition is due to two main factors - competition from other greenhouses in operation in Brantford and vicinity and the extreme difficulty of obtaining a qualified man to be in charge of the greenhouse.

In addition, the greenhouse has deteriorated and our officials feel that the time has now arrived to discontinue operation of the greenhouse as its educational value for the boys is negligible and it is impossible to operate it at a profit owing to the reasons stated above.

The building can be demolished very easily and any material salvaged can be used for other
purposes at the school or can be sold and the proceeds retained by the school for management expenses.

I would, therefore, appreciate it if the New England Company would consent to the demolishing of the greenhouse.

Please let me hear from you at your earliest convenience.

Yours sincerely,
